questionList.questionText: An unconscious 42-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after sustaining a gunshot wound to the chest during an attempted robbery at a convenience store.  The patient is minimally responsive to painful stimuli and is unable to provide a history.  The ambulance record indicates that his initial blood pressure was 120/70 mm Hg, pulse was 95/min, and respirations were 16/min.  On arrival, blood pressure is 70/40 mm Hg, pulse is 130/min, and respirations are 28/min.  He has an open gunshot wound in the chest and an exit wound in the back.  Intravenous fluids, vasopressors, and a blood transfusion are started.  The patient's wife arrives and says that his religious beliefs prohibit him from accepting blood products and that he would want the blood transfusion stopped.  The physician explains the risks of discontinuing the blood transfusion; the wife listens to the explanation but asks that the transfusion be stopped based on the patient's beliefs.  There is no advance directive, living will, or blood refusal card documenting the patient's wishes.  Blood pressure is 90/60 mm Hg and pulse is 120/min.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Next-of-kin surrogate decision maker

Patient selection

  • Inability to communicate wishes regarding medical decision-making
  • Advance directive not available or applicable
  • No previously designated surrogate decision maker

Surrogate selection

  • Priority to patient's spouse
  • Alternate: adult children, parents, adult siblings, other family members

Implementation

  • Substituted judgment: what the patient, not family, would have wanted
  • Decisions in the patient's best interest

This patient is in hemorrhagic shock, and his religious beliefs prohibiting blood transfusion became known only after blood transfusion had started.  Often, people with religious beliefs prohibiting the receipt of blood products carry an advance directive card to make their refusal of blood products explicit.  However, when there is no blood refusal card or advance directive (ie, living will, designated health care proxy), default surrogate decision makers are relied on to make medical decisions if the patient lacks capacity (eg, minimally responsive, altered level of consciousness).

In this scenario, the patient's wife is the default surrogate decision maker charged with using intimate knowledge of the patient to make medical decisions based on how the patient would have made them for himself (ie, substituted judgment standard).  If the surrogate decision maker cannot determine what the patient would have chosen, then decision-making is guided by what is in the patient's best interest (ie, what most people would want in that situation).  However, the wife has made the husband's likely wishes clear and reinforced the refusal of blood products after receiving an explanation of the risks involved.  Therefore, the blood transfusion should be stopped but other life-sustaining measures (eg, intravenous fluids, vasopressors) should be continued to stabilize his condition (Choices C and E).

(Choices A and B)  If surrogates of equal standing (eg, adult children) disagree on a course of treatment, then the hospital ethics committee could be asked for guidance in nonemergent situations.  If disagreement remains despite the ethics committee's involvement, then a court could be approached for resolution.  However, in this emergency situation, a clear default surrogate decision maker is present, and her decision should be acted on.

Educational objective:
In the absence of an advance directive (ie, living will, designated health care proxy), a default surrogate decision maker (eg, spouse, adult children) can consent to or refuse treatment, making decisions based on what the patient would have likely chosen in that scenario (ie, substituted judgment standard).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Advance directive/surrogate decision maker

answerChoiceList.choice: Continue the blood transfusion until an emergency court order can be obtained to discontinue it
Continue the blood transfusion until the hospital ethics committee can provide guidance
Continue the blood transfusion until the patient's condition is stabilized
Discontinue the blood transfusion and continue with other life-sustaining interventions
Discontinue the blood transfusion and provide comfort care only

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Operating one-handed: emergency treatment of Jehovah's Witnesses.

questionList.questionText: A 26-year old woman comes to the emergency department due to 2 days of palpitations, shortness of breath, and anxiety.  She has not had any chest pain or cough.  The patient has a history of generalized anxiety disorder and takes sertraline and an oral contraceptive.  She is sexually active with multiple partners, smokes 2 packs of cigarettes a week, and drinks 1-2 glasses of wine daily.  On physical examination, the patient appears visibly agitated.  Temperature is 37.6 C (99.7 F), blood pressure is 124/89 mm Hg, pulse is 102/min, and respirations are 18/min.  Serum electrolytes, complete blood count, cardiac enzymes, and chest x-ray are within normal limits.  ECG shows sinus tachycardia and is otherwise unremarkable.  The provider reviews the patient's chart and notes that she was seen last week in the emergency department with an identical chief complaint.  The assessment from this prior visit reads, "Given patient's history of generalized anxiety disorder, current symptoms likely represent panic attack."  The provider decides that she is having a repeat panic attack.  When the patient is about to be discharged, she suddenly enters cardiac arrest and cannot be resuscitated.  Autopsy reveals multiple large pulmonary emboli.  Which of the following factors most likely contributed to the missed diagnosis of pulmonary embolism in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Common cognitive errors in medicine

Type of bias

Definition

Example

Anchoring

  • Fixating on initial impressions to make a diagnosis
  • Related to confirmation bias & premature closure
  • Burning throat pain diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss
  • Correct diagnosis is lung malignancy

Availability

  • Allowing recently seen or memorable (high-stakes) cases to sway diagnosis
  • Dyspnea diagnosed as influenza during peak influenza season
  • Correct diagnosis is pulmonary embolism

Confirmation

  • Emphasizing evidence that supports presumed diagnosis & overlooking information that supports other diagnoses
  • Related to anchoring bias
  • Burning throat pain after eating spicy food diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss
  • Correct diagnosis is malignancy

Framing

  • Allowing diagnostic approach to be influenced by context & presentation of information
  • Abdominal pain diagnosed as opioid withdrawal in patient described as drug seeking
  • Correct diagnosis is bowel obstruction

Diagnostic errors (ie, missed or delayed diagnoses) are often caused by misinterpretation of clinical data, and account for up to 17% of hospital adverse events.  They can arise from factors relating to the physician (eg, fatigue), the patient (eg, language barrier), or the system (eg, inefficient workflow).  Diagnostic errors often result from cognitive bias, occurring when a physician's dependence on heuristics (ie, mental shortcuts) distorts clinical judgment and treatment.

This scenario illustrates several types of cognitive bias:

  • Framing bias occurred as the context of information (ie, medical record describing panic attack history and diagnosis of generalized anxiety disorder) incorrectly limited the physician's "frame" of analysis.  This bias led to the assumption that tachycardia, shortness of breath, and anxiety also represented a panic attack, rather than possible pulmonary embolism.

  • Anchoring bias led to the physician fixating ("anchoring") on a presumptive diagnosis of panic attack without considering alternate causes.

  • Confirmation bias resulted in the physician's oversight of information contradicting the presumptive diagnosis, including the patient's risk factors of smoking and oral contraceptive use.

(Choice A)  Communication error typically describes a breakdown in information relay, such as a change in clinical care or a lack of closed-loop communication within the medical team.  In this scenario, there are no communication breakdowns to explain the patient's misdiagnosis.

(Choice B)  Documentation error often occurs when information is omitted from the medical record (eg, not charting pertinent physical examination findings).  There is no evidence of documentation error in this scenario.

(Choice D)  Information bias describes the belief that more data is better, leading to overcollection of data, which can complicate efficient and accurate decision-making.  In this case, the physician's cognitive bias resulted in collecting an insufficient, rather than an excessive, amount of data for diagnostic workup.

(Choice E)  Latent errors are system-level factors, such as inefficient protocols or organizational structures, that cause adverse events.  This case represents an active error (ie, relating to the physician's specific actions or judgement) caused by cognitive bias, rather than a system-level error.

Educational objective:
Diagnostic errors are commonly caused by cognitive bias, including framing, anchoring, and confirmation bias.  Framing bias occurs when contextual information (eg, previous diagnosis) influences a physician's judgment, resulting in failure to consider alternate diagnoses.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Cognitive error

answerChoiceList.choice: Communication error
Documentation error
Framing bias
Information bias
Latent error

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Cognitive psychology of missed diagnoses.
Achieving quality in clinical decision making: cognitive strategies and detection of bias.
Medical error prevention.

questionList.questionText: Researchers are planning a clinical trial to test the optimal dose, frequency, and effectiveness of magnetic brain stimulation therapy for the treatment of moderate to severe depression.  Participants are eligible to enroll if they have had moderate to severe depression for >1 year.  The intervention involves 6 weeks of weekly 2-hour sessions using an MRI machine.  For convenient access and follow-up, the researchers plan to recruit all participants from a local community resource center that provides social and employment assistance for many of the lowest income families in the area.  As compensation, the researchers will provide each participant with 6 weeks' worth of standard minimum-wage salaries along with free meals for participants and families at the resource center during the trial.  Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding this study's recruitment plan?
questionList.explanationText:
The recruitment plan for this clinical trial exclusively involves a vulnerable population (ie, low-income families in a community resource center) to test a specialized treatment for moderate to severe depression.  While involvement of vulnerable populations in research is often appropriate, historical patterns of unethical or disproportionate recruitment of vulnerable groups (eg, low-income, institutionalized) has raised concerns for exploitation.  In such cases, vulnerable groups may unfairly be exposed to research risks but not resulting benefits (eg, high-cost or inaccessible therapeutic advancements).

Subject recruitment for clinical research should therefore include the following features:

  • Compensation to participants should be proportionate to their actual participation time (eg, hourly wage × number of hours spent on research activities) and associated expenses (eg, transportation, childcare).  Given this study's requirement time commitent (2 hours/week for 6 weeks = 12 hours), its compensation plan (ie, 6 weeks' worth of salary, meals) is excessive and likely to constitute inducement.  Inducement potentially incentivizes participants to overlook otherwise unacceptable personal risks and undermines patient autonomy during informed consent (Choice B).

  • The recruitment plan should relate directly to the study's primary objectives.  In this study, planned recruitment is based primarily on convenience (eg, ease of access) rather than research relevance (ie, nothing in this study's objective relates to depression management specifically in low-income communities).

  • Unless research goals specify otherwise, subject recruitment should target a range of demographic groups to ensure equitable distribution of research risks and increase generalizability of study findings.  This recruitment plan excludes large segments of the broader community (eg, more affluent populations), thereby concentrating research risks primarily in one demographic group.

(Choice A)  The vulnerable group recruited for this study is exposed to research risks but is unlikely to access the benefits of the study's findings (eg, specialized MRI treatments, if found to be beneficial, are likely expensive and inaccessible to uninsured patients); therefore, such research is not likely to promote health equity and justice.

(Choice D)  Moderate to severe depression is common and often increased by financial stress, so the recruited participants are likely to satisfy the study's inclusion criteria.  Inducement and poor practical applicability of any potential research benefits in this population are more pressing ethical concerns.

Educational objective:
Excessive compensation to research participants is inappropriate because it constitutes inducement (by incentivizing participants to overlook risks they may have otherwise considered as unacceptable), particularly for vulnerable (eg, low-income) populations.  Compensation should be based only on the participants' actual time for study participation and associated expenses.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Research ethics

answerChoiceList.choice: The recruitment plan is appropriate because it is likely to promote health equity
The recruitment plan is appropriate because participants are financially compensated
The recruitment plan is not appropriate because it is likely to constitute inducement
The recruitment plan is not appropriate because the participants are unlikely to satisfy inclusion criteria

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Bioethical issues in providing financial incentives to research participants.

questionList.questionText:
A 12-year-old girl is brought to the clinic by her parents for evaluation of decreased exercise tolerance and increased lethargy.  Her parents say she becomes short of breath with minimal exertion, and for the past 2 weeks her gums have bled when she brushes her teeth.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98 F); blood pressure and pulse are normal.  Physical examination demonstrates pallor and hepatosplenomegaly.  Laboratory results are as follows:

Complete blood count
    Hemoglobin6.8 g/dL
    Platelets20,000/mm3
    Leukocytes40,000/mm3
    Blast cells15%

An extensive workup indicates that the patient has acute lymphoblastic leukemia, and the parents are informed that she will need chemotherapy.  The parents do not consent to the treatment plan because they believe that the side effects will be too severe and that their child's quality of life will be poor.  Despite an ethics consultation and a lengthy discussion about the benefits of treatment and likely consequences if therapy is withheld, the parents insist on taking her home without scheduling follow-up treatment.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Although parents generally have the right to make medical decisions for their minor children, parents cannot refuse life-saving treatment for a child.  In this case, the parents are refusing a proven life-saving treatment for their child.  Treatment of acute lymphoblastic leukemia currently offers a survival rate of over 80%.  Without treatment, acute lymphoblastic leukemia commonly results in death.

The physician should continue to engage the parents, explaining the benefits of treatment and the consequences of withholding diagnostic tests and chemotherapy.  The hospital ethics committee, social services, and hospital risk management can also assist.  In some cases, this multidisciplinary approach will enable parents to overcome their fears and consent to the proposed treatment.  However, if the parents continue to refuse life-saving treatment, the physician should seek a court order to proceed with the necessary intervention.

(Choice A)  Complying with parental wishes is not in the best interest of this child.  Therefore, the physician has an ethical duty to advocate for the child and petition the court to intervene in favor of life-saving chemotherapy.

(Choice C)  If a delay for consent is life-threatening, emergency treatment for the child is legally authorized regardless of the parents' wishes.  However, this is a nonemergency situation, so authorization should be sought through legal channels.

(Choice D)  Providing only supportive care is inadequate treatment for this girl's leukemia and would likely result in death.  Therefore, the physician should petition the court to intervene.

(Choice E)  Transfer of care to another provider would delay pursuing a court order for life-saving chemotherapy.

Educational objective:
In a nonemergency situation in which a parent refuses potentially life-saving treatment for their child, the physician should seek a court order mandating treatment.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Refusal of treatment

answerChoiceList.choice: Comply with the parents' wishes
Obtain a court order for chemotherapy
Proceed with chemotherapy immediately
Provide supportive treatment only
Recommend transfer of care to another provider

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Parents know best: or do they? Treatment refusals in paediatric oncology.

questionList.questionText: A 65-year-old man with a history of obesity, aortic stenosis, and coronary artery disease is undergoing combined valve repair and coronary artery bypass grafting.  Multiple complications prolong the case by several hours.  As the surgeon is preparing to complete the procedure, a scrub nurse is counting the number of sponges and instruments and notices the tip of a surgical suction catheter used to irrigate the chest cavity is missing.  He brings this to the surgeon's attention and suggests a chest x-ray be ordered prior to closing the wound.  The surgeon disagrees and responds that the x-ray should be deferred until after the case is completed.  The postoperative film reveals the catheter tip inside the chest, necessitating the patient's return to the operating room for retrieval.  Which of the following interventions is most likely to prevent a root cause of this error?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of effective teams* in health care

Safety culture

  • Resource commitment to safety

Collaboration

  • Shared understanding & prioritization of goals
  • Distinct roles that avoid a steep hierarchy

Psychologic safety

  • Asking questions & voicing concerns encouraged
  • Avoiding blame or retaliation

Responsiveness

  • Feedback respected & promptly acted on

Situational awareness

  • Persistent mindfulness & safety vigilance
  • Cross-checking of each other's actions

Transparency

  • Prompt disclosure of errors & safety information

*Poor teamwork is a leading root cause of sentinel events; improved communication reduces medical errors & improves patient/clinical outcomes.

Retained foreign objects (RFOs), which are more common in prolonged surgeries and patients with obesity, constitute a sentinel event (ie, serious medical error resulting in irreversible patient harm).  This nurse detected a missing catheter tip and suggested an appropriate action (ie, intraoperative x-ray); however, the surgeon's response prevented prompt assessment and prevention of the RFO.  This interaction illustrates poor teamwork and communication, which are leading root causes (ie, system-level factors) of sentinel events.

Simulation training is a method of interactive group learning in which teams learn and practice skills together in simulated cases (eg, suspected RFO during complex surgery).  It improves teamwork and is used frequently in high-reliability organizations (ie, high risk industries with excellent safety records) to promote safety.

In this case, simulation training could address root causes of this RFO by improving team skills in:

  • Responsiveness (eg, nurse clearly asserting safety concerns; surgeon respecting and fully addressing nurse's concerns)
  • Collaboration (eg, surgeon and nurse sharing and prioritizing safety goals and demonstrating respectful communication)
  • Situational awareness (eg, surgeon and nurse both being aware of and vigilant for threats to safety)

RFO prevention also necessitates conducting repeated counts of sponges and instruments (ie, manual reconciliation of counts) prior to completing surgery.  However, relying on repeated manual counts to prevent RFO is error prone (in >80% of RFOs, staff believed counts to be correct) and does not address root causes of poor teamwork.  For example, repeating sponge and instrument counts would not prevent RFO in this situation because a count discrepancy was already suspected and brought to the surgeon's attention, but incorrectly dismissed (reflecting poor team responsiveness and situational awareness) (Choice D).

(Choice A)  Anonymous incident reporting systems can minimize fear of retaliation and increase error reporting but would not prevent this RFO incident, in which the error was already detected in the team's presence.

(Choices B and C)  Disciplinary actions may be necessary in certain cases (eg, repeated errors despite support, or willful harm), and burnout can increase error.  However, simulation training is a more active, group-based form improvement (in contrast to passive learning at a seminar), and is generally more effective in improving RFO root causes of poor teamwork.

Educational objective:
Poor teamwork (eg, miscommunication, low responsiveness) is a leading root cause of retained foreign objects in surgical settings.  Simulation training is a hands-on teamwork training method, which improves safety skills such as situational awareness, responsiveness, and communication.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Creating anonymous incident reporting systems
Disciplinary action for all team members involved in the case
Having providers attend an informational seminar on burnout
Repeating sponge and instrument counts
Simulation training in team-based safety communication

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Risk factors for retained instruments and sponges after surgery.
Simulation: translation to improved team performance.
A multidisciplinary team approach to retained foreign objects.
The ongoing quality improvement journey: next stop, high reliability.

questionList.questionText: A 17-year-old boy is hospitalized with an acute exacerbation of cystic fibrosis.  His respiratory function had remained stable for many years but began to deteriorate, with 3 hospital admissions within the past 6 months.  The patient's FEV1/FVC ratio has decreased compared with a baseline reading 9 months ago and is now 30% of predicted value.  He is placed on supplemental oxygen and antimicrobial therapy and given inhaled bronchodilators.  The hospitalist physician notices that there is no advance directive for this patient.  Which of the following is the most appropriate action in patient care?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with cystic fibrosis (CF) has experienced an increased frequency of pulmonary exacerbations and a decrease in FEV1.  These findings correlate with decreased survival and therefore warrant timely discussion about advance care planning.

In cases involving minors with a chronic and life-limiting illness, such as CF, incorporating them in a developmentally appropriate manner (eg, involving this patient in a discussion about options and advance care preferences) emphasizes their role as a participant in care alongside the parents.  The family-centered advance care planning approach is an effective tool for parents and adolescent patients and helps reduce adolescent anxiety and maintain a high quality of life.

In this scenario, the patient should be involved in discussions with health care providers and parents about prognosis, treatment options with risks and benefits of each, and the patient's and family's preferences for end-of-life care.  Involving the patient and engaging in a dialogue with parents facilitates an understanding of the patient's priorities and values along with those of the parents' to best ensure that everyone's wishes can be honored should a life-threatening complication occur.

(Choices A and B)  A primary care clinician who knows the patient well is in the ideal position to initiate a discussion about advance care planning.  However, given this patient's deteriorating clinical status, it is inappropriate to delay the conversation until after discharge (should he develop a significant respiratory decompensation during this hospitalization) or until he turns age 18 (the age of legal consent in most jurisdictions).

(Choice C)  Deferring advance care planning discussions risks not knowing patient preferences should his status decline while hospitalized.  Furthermore, family-centered advance care planning has shown to be perceived by adolescents as useful, worthwhile, and relieving while helping to maintain mood, preserve a high quality of life, and reduce anxiety levels.

(Choice E)  Parents have ultimate legal authority regarding health care decisions for their minor children; however, adolescents have a maturing capacity to appreciate the medical implications of chronic and terminal conditions.  Physicians should encourage parents to include minors in treatment decisions, including advance care planning, as developmentally appropriate.

Educational objective:
Discussions regarding advance care planning for adolescents with chronic, life-limiting illnesses (eg, cystic fibrosis) should take a family-centered approach and involve the adolescent patient alongside the parents.  Discussion should include information regarding prognosis, care options, and the patient's and family's preferences for end-of-life care.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Advance directive/surrogate decision maker

answerChoiceList.choice: Advise the patient to start advance care planning when he turns age 18
Contact the patient's primary care physician and recommend that a discussion take place after discharge
Defer a discussion until the patient's condition has stabilized so that he does not lose motivation to participate in treatment
Involve the patient in a discussion about treatment options and advance care directives
Obtain the parents' preferences and implement their directives as soon as possible

questionMappingReferencesList.title: A longitudinal, randomized, controlled trial of advance care planning for teens with cancer: anxiety, depression, quality of life, advance directives, spirituality.
Acceptability of family-centered advanced care planning for adolescents with HIV.

questionList.questionText: A 65-year-old heavy smoker with a lengthy history of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease comes to the office due to recent-onset hemoptysis.  He reports 3-5 episodes of coughing up blood in the past month.  The patient also reports a 9.1-kg (20-lb) weight loss in the past 2 months.  Chest radiograph reveals a suspicious lesion, and a bronchoscopy followed by biopsy establishes the diagnosis of squamous cell carcinoma of the lung.  When the patient is informed of his condition and the prognosis, he asks that no one in his family be told the news yet.  He seems tearful but cognitively intact.  His wife, who usually brings him to his visits and is also his health care proxy, calls the next day to inquire about the pathology results.  She says she is deeply concerned because her husband is reluctant to discuss his condition.  Which of the following is the most appropriate course of action?
questionList.explanationText:
Confidentiality is a patient's right to health privacy.  A patient's desire for confidentiality can conflict with a family member's wish to be involved, because it is likely that the family, too, will be affected by the diagnosis.  In this situation, the patient has directed the physician to maintain complete privacy regarding his diagnosis and prognosis.  Out of respect for patient confidentiality, the physician may not disclose any information to the patient's wife without permission.

However, the physician should seek to understand the patient's rationale for keeping his diagnosis private.  Oftentimes, patients are reluctant to disclose a serious diagnosis (eg, squamous cell carcinoma of the lung) because of personal values, family dynamics, or cultural practices.  Discussing his preferences for receiving support may help the patient devise an eventual plan for disclosure.  Rushing the patient to disclose, or threatening to disclose on his behalf, is inappropriate (Choice D).

(Choices A and E)  Health care proxies are designated to make medical decisions for patients who lack capacity (eg, delirious, unconscious).  This patient is cognitively intact; therefore, even though the wife is this patient's health care proxy, she cannot access his medical information or overrule his decision for nondisclosure.

(Choice B)  Showing empathy for the wife (eg, "I'm sorry the situation is causing you concern") and voicing understanding are acceptable; however, the physician must still respectfully convey that no medical information can be shared without the patient's permission.

(Choice C)  Statements like "your husband will receive comprehensive care" may seem like harmless attempts to offer reassurance, but they should be avoided because the tone and subtext hint at a serious diagnosis (eg, cancer); in contrast, a benign biopsy result would probably not merit a vow to provide comprehensive care.

Educational objective:
Patients may not wish to disclose medical information to their families based on personal values, family dynamics, or cultural practices.  Patient confidentiality, including directives to limit family access to personal medical information, should be respected.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient confidentiality

answerChoiceList.choice: Ask the wife to come to the office with a copy of the patient's health care proxy form.
In response to the wife's concerns, ask her to come to the office to further review the patient's status.
In response to the wife's concerns, inform her that the patient will receive comprehensive care.
Inform the patient that his wife must eventually be told if the patient refuses to do so himself.
Inform the wife of the pathology report results because she is the patient's health care proxy.
Inform the wife that you are not able to discuss the patient's information.

questionMappingReferencesList.title: American College of Physicians ethics manual: seventh edition.

questionList.questionText: Administrators at a busy multicenter hospital are concerned about a higher-than-average incidence of retained surgical objects (RSO) following complex abdominal surgery.  Current hospital procedures require the circulating nurse and a scrub nurse to conduct an initial count of surgical sponges and instruments before surgery begins; this number must then be reconciled during a final count prior to finishing the procedure.  However, the administrators find that most instances of RSO occurred even when nurses had followed hospital counting procedures and reconciled the final count.  Upon reviewing video recordings of the teams working in the operative setting, the administrators note that counts are time-intensive, constituting 15% of total operation time.  In addition, during the final count, nurses experience distractions, such as alarms and background music, and frequent interruptions from surgeons asking the nurses for items necessary to close the incision.  Which of the following interventions is recommended to improve quality of the counting procedure in this setting?
questionList.explanationText:
Retained surgical objects (RSO) (eg, sponges, instruments) carry potentially serious patient consequences (eg, infection, reoperation).  To detect RSO, hospitals typically require 2 nurses to reconcile counts of objects and instruments used during surgery.  However, counting can be tedious, time-intensive, and error-prone; up to 80% of RSOs occur in cases that include an appropriate reconciliation count.

Distractions and interruptions are a major contributor to counting errors.  At this hospital, nurses are frequently interrupted by surgeons needing items (eg, tools, sutures) to close the incision, and the surgeons, who are concentrating on operative tasks, may be unaware that nurses have initiated the count.  To reduce counting errors, a brief time-out (ie, a dedicated pause where nurses announce that a final count is about to begin) may be performed to improve team awareness.  This can reduce counting errors through the following:

  • Makes team members aware that an important safety action is about to begin, and that they should limit unnecessary interruptions

  • Allows the surgeons to request anticipated tools and items before the count, reducing interruptions once the count has started

(Choice A)  Addressing team authority levels and possible intimidation promotes free expression of safety concerns (eg, nurses freely voice concern about suspected count discrepancy).  However, in this case, interruptions most likely occur from low situational awareness (eg, multitasking; surgeons unaware that counting has begun) rather than intimidation by surgeons.  A time-out is more likely to increase awareness of safety proceedings and minimize interruptions, improving counting accuracy.

(Choice B)  Closed-loop communication, in which the receiver of a message repeats it back to the sender, prevents miscommunication.  However, it would not address the frequency of interruptions or low situational awareness causing counting errors.

(Choice C)  Counting procedures are already time-intensive; repeating the counts is likely to be impractical and does not address the distractable, interruption-prone environment.

Educational objective:
Retained surgical objects (eg, sponges, instruments) frequently occur even when surgical counts are thought to be reconciled.  Interruptions increase the risk of counting error; holding a brief time-out (ie, a pause in activities to announce that the count is about to begin) can improve situational awareness (ie, group vigilance for safety concerns), reduce interruptions, and improve count quality.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Addressing levels of authority and intimidation within teams
Engaging teams in simulation-based exercises focusing on closed-loop communication
Having another team member independently repeat the count after the final count is completed
Having nurses call a brief time-out prior to starting the final counting process

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Prevalence and characteristics of interruptions and distractions during surgical counts.

questionList.questionText: A 20-year-old woman at 40 weeks gestation, Group B Streptococcus (GBS) positive, comes to the labor and delivery department of a large tertiary care hospital for scheduled delivery induction.  The membranes are ruptured, and the patient asks for epidural pain management.  While waiting for the anesthesiologist, a labor and delivery nurse accesses bags of intravenous fluid, intravenous penicillin, and epidural solution from an automated medication cabinet in the room.  The bags are of similar size and appearance.  The nurse attaches a bag to the patient's intravenous line and begins infusion, believing it is penicillin intended for GBS chemoprophylaxis.  Within a few minutes, the patient experiences cardiovascular collapse and cannot be resuscitated.  It is later discovered that the incorrect bag was attached, resulting in intravenous administration of epidural solution (bupivacaine) rather than penicillin.  Which of the following interventions is most likely to eliminate the possibility of a similar error occurring?
questionList.explanationText:
Human factors engineering strategies

Reliability

Strategy

Description & examples

Highest

Forcing functions

  • Hard stops in design or process to eliminate risk for incorrect use
  • Example: each anesthesia gas fits only one compatible socket & is not interchangeable

Computerized automation

  • Automated processes to remove human effort & variations that cause error
  • Example: automated vital signs monitoring

Environment & physical layout

  • Workspace design to facilitate correct action & minimize error
  • Example: look-alike drugs stocked in different locations

High

Standardization & simplification

  • Uniform processes to minimize variation, complexity & learning curve
  • Example: every hospital unit follows the same process for heparin administration

Human-machine redundancy

  • Repetitive step to confirm correct action in an error-prone process
  • Example: barcode scanning of medications in addition to visual inspection

Medium

Reminders, alerts & double-checks

  • Processes prompting providers to check actions to reduce errors
  • Examples: drug-drug interaction alerts; time-out before procedures

HFE seeks to reduce error risk by designing systems based on expected human behaviors.  Less reliable HFE strategies include training, policy changes & education.

HFE = human factors engineering.

This patient's cardiovascular collapse resulted from accidental intravenous administration of bupivacaine, a medication meant for epidural catheter use only.  Medication administration errors occur frequently and rarely result from provider negligence alone.  Contributing latent factors (ie, systemic causes) include use of look-alike medications (eg, penicillin and epidural solution), and heavy workload in busy settings (eg, labor and delivery ward of a tertiary care hospital) which promotes workarounds (ie, bypassing protocols to improve efficiency, such as accessing epidural medications ahead of the procedure).  Human factors engineering (HFE) reduces error risk by designing systems that consider and correct for anticipated human limitations in complex environments.

HFE strategies follow a hierarchy of effectiveness.  The most effective strategies involve physical design changes removing reliance on human effort for correct action:

  • Forcing functions are hard stops in a design or process preventing incorrect action.  In this example, designing epidural bags to be physically incompatible with peripheral intravenous catheters represents a forcing function eliminating the possibility of intravenous infusion, even if the wrong bag is selected.

  • Computerized automation uses technology to replace human effort (eg, automated monitoring of vital signs every 4 hours), increasing reliability and reducing erroneous variation.

Comparatively less effective HFE strategies incorporate physical design changes, but place greater reliance on human effort:

  • Visual cues include packaging or label designs alerting providers to error risk, for example, brightly colored stickers on epidural solution bags (Choice C).

  • Redundancy introduces double-checks or repetitive steps in a process, for example, requiring providers to scan medication bar codes in addition to visual inspection (Choice D).

Unlike forcing functions, these strategies do not eliminate the possibility of error because they are vulnerable to workarounds and alert fatigue (ie, phenomenon of decreased attention with frequent exposure to visual and auditory input).

The least effective HFE strategies rely mostly on human effort for safe action.  These include education (eg, in-service training) and policies (eg, policy prohibiting early access of epidural medications).  These interventions are still needed, but are unlikely to eliminate error if used alone (Choices A and B).

Educational objective:
Human factors engineering (HFE) designs systems based on expected human behaviors to reduce errors.  The most effective HFE interventions involve physical changes that facilitate safe action without human effort.  An example is forcing functions, or hard stops in a process or design (eg, epidural solution bags incompatible with peripheral catheters) that eliminate the possibility of error.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Conducting in-service training for nurses on medication protocols and safe use
Creating a policy that prohibits access of epidural medications ahead of procedure
Placing brightly colored warning stickers on bags of epidural solution
Requiring providers to scan medication bar codes prior to administration
Using epidural bags that are incompatible with peripheral intravenous tubing

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Shaping systems for better behavioral choices: lessons learned from a fatal medication error.

questionList.questionText: A quality assurance committee is establishing best practices for ordering various laboratory and imaging studies in an emergency department.  They find that one physician orders significantly more CT scans of the head compared to other physicians in the department.  The physician states that he orders more head CT scans on young patients with chronic migraines, even those with normal examination and unremarkable history, because he recently missed a diagnosis of intracranial bleed in an 18-year old patient with a history of chronic migraines.  Which of the following most likely explains this physician's tendency to now order excessive CT scans of the head?
questionList.explanationText:
Common cognitive errors in medicine

Type of bias

Definition

Example

Anchoring

  • Fixating on initial impressions to make a diagnosis
  • Related to confirmation bias & premature closure
  • Burning throat pain diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss
  • Correct diagnosis is lung malignancy

Availability

  • Allowing recently seen or memorable (high-stakes) cases to sway diagnosis
  • Dyspnea diagnosed as influenza during peak influenza season
  • Correct diagnosis is pulmonary embolism

Confirmation

  • Emphasizing evidence that supports presumed diagnosis & overlooking information that supports other diagnoses
  • Related to anchoring bias
  • Burning throat pain after eating spicy food diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss
  • Correct diagnosis is malignancy

Framing

  • Allowing diagnostic approach to be influenced by context & presentation of information
  • Abdominal pain diagnosed as opioid withdrawal in patient described as drug seeking
  • Correct diagnosis is bowel obstruction

Cognitive errors are unconscious biases adversely influencing clinical judgment and leading to diagnostic error.  They often involve heuristics, mental shortcuts formed based on patterns and learned associations.  Heuristics represent fast, unconscious thinking (eg, impulse) rather than measured, rational analysis; physicians who are fatigued or who work in busy clinical settings are more likely to rely on heuristics to increase diagnostic efficiency.

This physician started ordering unnecessary head CT scans after missing a diagnosis of intracranial bleed; this behavior reflects availability bias.  Availability bias (or "recency effect") occurs when a memorable ("high-stakes"), often recent case biases subsequent judgment and decision-making.  This physician's recent experience created a mental heuristic to order head CT scans on patients with migraines.  As seen in this scenario, availability bias commonly causes excessive diagnostic workup and overtreatment.

Cognitive bias can be minimized by increasing physician awareness (eg, morbidity and mortality meetings), encouraging systematic analysis (eg, quick-access electronic tools to calculate pre-test probability), and optimizing the environment (eg, additional staff to reduce physician burden).

(Choice B)  Data misinterpretation, a cause of diagnostic error, may result from cognitive bias.  For example, confirmation bias can result in overlooking potentially concerning information on imaging or laboratory data in a patient with headache.  Data misinterpretation and confirmation bias may have triggered the physician's initial missed diagnosis in the patient with migraine.  However, his tendency to subsequently order CT scans on low-risk patients with headache reflects availability bias.

(Choice C)  Documentation error involves inaccurate or incomplete record-keeping (eg, not documenting pertinent physical examination findings, copy-and-pasting outdated information).  Documentation is not a contributing factor in this scenario.

(Choice D)  Knowledge deficiency (eg, insufficient ability to interpret clinical data) is a rarer cause of diagnostic error for practicing physicians compared with cognitive error.  This physician's behavior started after a recent patient experience; therefore, knowledge deficiency regarding head CT imaging indications is unlikely.

Educational objective:
Cognitive errors involve heuristics (mental shortcuts) incorrectly influencing clinical decision-making, resulting in diagnostic error.  Availability bias describes the tendency for recent or notable clinical experiences to bias subsequent clinical judgment, and often causes excessive diagnostic workup.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Cognitive error

answerChoiceList.choice: Availability bias
Data misinterpretation
Documentation error
Knowledge deficiency

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Achieving quality in clinical decision making: cognitive strategies and detection of bias.
Improving patient care: the cognitive psychology of missed diagnoses.

questionList.questionText: A physician goes to labor and delivery on Friday evening to check on the labor progression of her patient.  The patient has had a protracted labor course throughout the day.  Cervical dilation has increased 1 cm over the last 3 hours, and she is now at 8 cm dilation.  Vital signs are normal, and the fetal heart rate tracing is category 1.  The physician is leaving town for vacation in a few hours, but an on-call obstetrician will be available for later deliveries.  The current physician recommends performing a cesarean delivery now because of the protracted labor course and this physician's inability to attend the delivery in a few hours.  This situation demonstrates which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient's active phase of labor has been protracted.  However, her vital signs and fetal heart rate tracing are reassuring, and vaginal delivery could still be possible if her contractions are optimized (eg, oxytocin augmentation).  Although the current physician is leaving town for vacation in a few hours, there is still an on-call obstetrician available for later deliveries.  Therefore, the most appropriate management is to continue labor for a possible vaginal delivery, even if the current physician cannot attend (and therefore charge for) the delivery.

Instead, this situation demonstrates a conflict of interest because the current physician's recommendation (cesarean delivery now) is out of self-interest and/or personal convenience (ie, expediting delivery prior to leaving for vacation), thereby influencing or biasing the process of informed consent.  Physicians are obligated to inform the patient of all medically reasonable alternatives (eg, labor augmentation vs proceeding to cesarean delivery) and to provide medical care that is most likely to yield the greatest benefit to the patient, regardless of personal interest.

(Choice A)  Vaginal delivery may still be achievable in this patient, and it has fewer maternal risks and shorter recovery times.  Therefore, the current physician's recommendation for cesarean delivery does not demonstrate beneficence.

(Choice C)  Directive counseling occurs when the physician assumes an active role in directing the patient toward a management option (eg, cesarean delivery for vasa previa, placenta previa) because it is the only medically reasonable option with clearly superior evidence-based support.

(Choice D)  Justice is the ethical principle of fair and equitable treatment, such as equal distribution of scarce medical resources, lack of discrimination when providing medical care, and adherence to applicable laws.

(Choice E)  Preventive ethics occurs when a consent process helps anticipate and prevent future ethical issues.  An example is obtaining informed consent at a routine obstetric visit for cesarean delivery rather than intrapartum when emergency decisions may be required.

(Choice F)  In this situation, veracity (ie, being truthful to patients) would occur if the physician acknowledged that vaginal delivery is still possible and safe for this patient and that a cesarean delivery is not required.

Educational objective:
Conflict of interest occurs when the process of informed consent is influenced or biased by a physician's self-interest.  Physicians are obligated to inform patients of all medically reasonable alternatives and provide care that is most likely to yield the greatest benefit to the patient.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Informed consent

answerChoiceList.choice: Beneficence
Conflict of interest
Directive counseling
Justice
Preventive ethics
Veracity

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Informed consent–it's more than a signature on a piece of paper.

questionList.questionText: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by the police after trying to walk across a busy highway.  The patient is alert and oriented to self only.  She refuses vital signs, glucose testing, and a urine sample.  The physician introduces himself; moments later, the patient stands and pushes him backward.  The physician is able to exit the room and alert nursing and security staff.  The patient continues to be verbally threatening and attempts to lunge at the physician when he returns to the examination room.  She is physically restrained by staff and intramuscular lorazepam is administered.  Once the patient is no longer agitated, physical restraints are promptly discontinued, and the physician continues the evaluation.  Which of the following is the most accurate statement regarding this scenario?
questionList.explanationText:
Ethical principles in medicine

Principle

Duty

Beneficence

Promote good & act in the best medical interests of the patient

Nonmaleficence

Do no harm to the patient

Autonomy

Protect & facilitate the patient's individual, informed decisions

Justice

Equally distribute health care resources & provide fair & equitable treatment

Proportionality

Ensure that methods used to achieve a worthwhile goal are necessary, appropriate & not excessive

Proportionality is the ethical principle that considers whether an intended goal ("the end") is sufficiently worthwhile and ensures that the methods used ("the means") to achieve it are necessary, reasonable, and not excessive.  "The end justifies the means" describes a goal so important that any method, even if harsh, may be used to achieve it.  Upholding proportionality means that the benefits of an intervention outweigh the risks and that the degree of intervention is appropriate.

In this scenario, proportionality was upheld in the medical management of a patient without decisional capacity.  This patient is alert but delirious (ie, oriented to self only), has refused medical care, and poses an imminent danger to herself and others (eg, lunging at and threatening the physician).  The goal is to protect the patient and staff from harm and to facilitate an emergency evaluation for life-threatening causes of her delirium.

Given the importance of these goals, the use of physical restraints and medication is necessary, reasonable, and not excessive because lesser interventions (eg, continuing with verbal de-escalation only) would unreasonably risk greater harm and delay emergency care.  In accordance with proportionality, restraints are removed immediately once the acute danger has passed, thereby curbing excessive force.

(Choice A)  Capacity is determined by a patient's ability to understand and make informed decisions.  This patient's lack of decisional capacity is due to acute delirium; it is not based on her refusal of care or inability to maintain personal safety because a patient with intact decisional capacity can still refuse care at the risk of personal safety.

(Choice B)  Respect for autonomy means upholding a patient's informed decision.  Patients without capacity are, by definition, incapable of making informed decisions.  In this situation, an evaluation is medically necessary and does not violate autonomy in this situation.

(Choice C)  Beneficence involves acting in the best medical interests of the patient, which may include restrictive protocols in delirious patients to limit danger and to facilitate emergency evaluation.

(Choice E)  Justice refers to the equal distribution of health care resources and the provision of fair and equitable healthcare to all people.  This principle was upheld when the patient was brought to the emergency department for medical care.

Educational objective:
Proportionality ensures that sufficiently worthwhile goals are achieved by necessary, reasonable, and nonexcessive methods.  An example is the use of physical restraints to maintain patient safety when nonrestrictive options are insufficient, followed by immediate removal of the restraints once danger passes.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Ethical principles in healthcare

answerChoiceList.choice: The patient lacked decisional capacity because she refused care and was unable to maintain personal safety
The physician failed to respect patient autonomy when he attempted to examine the patient following administration of lorazepam
The physician violated the principle of beneficence when he ordered physical restraints and lorazepam for the patient
The physician's management of the patient's physical aggression upheld the principle of proportionality
The principle of justice was violated when the patient was brought by the police to the emergency department

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Proportionality, pandemics, and medical ethics.
American College of Physicians ethics manual: seventh edition.

questionList.questionText: A hospitalist who covers a cardiac ward in a tertiary care medical center notices that a hospital-based cardiologist, with whom she has worked for several years, is increasingly difficult to reach.  The cardiologist now takes several hours to respond when he is paged while on call, appears distracted and irritable during discussions, and leaves his patient consult notes incomplete for longer than 48 hours.  The hospitalist has also noticed that the cardiologist has been rounding at 11:00 PM; she once heard him mention "a family emergency" to one of the nurses.  He has told the hospitalist that she can always call one of his partners as a backup if he does not answer pages.  The hospitalist has not noticed any medical errors made by the cardiologist.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step by the hospitalist?
questionList.explanationText:
Physician impairment

Definition

  • Impaired ability to practice medicine competently & safely due to psychiatric/medical illness, alcohol, or drug dependency

Recognition

  • Lateness, unexplained absences, inaccessibility
  • Unusual rounding times
  • Inappropriate orders, prescriptions errors, incorrect charting
  • Increased irritability, anger, conflicts with staff & colleagues
  • Overt signs of substance misuse/abuse (eg, excessive drinking at hospital functions, slurred speech, smell of alcohol, poor hygiene, needle marks)
  • Increase in patient complaints
  • Deterioration in clinical performance (usually a late sign)

Management

  • Report to PHP
  • Refusal to comply with PHP recommendations may result in the provider being reported to the state medical board

PHP = Physician Health Program.

This cardiologist's behavior should raise concern for physician impairment, defined as impaired ability to practice medicine competently and safely.  Signs of impairment include being increasingly difficult to reach, unusually late rounding times, decreased chart performance, and increased irritability and distractibility in clinical discussions.  Deterioration in clinical performance is typically a late sign indicative of more severe impairment.

Physicians are ethically obligated to report suspected physician impairment.  In the interests of patient safety and preventing medical errors, this should be done regardless of whether other staff has expressed similar concerns or patient complaints have been filed.  Reports are made to Physician Health Programs (PHPs), which are typically hospital-based organizations designated to investigate reported concerns and arrange for a comprehensive assessment of the physician to help identify substance use and/or psychiatric/medical illness.  If there is no designated PHP, the relevant chief of service should be informed.

PHPs are confidential resources that provide extensive support and expert education and monitoring.  If intervention is required, the PHP can assist the physician in getting necessary treatment.  Recovery rates are much higher than the general population, including among physicians involuntarily referred to PHPs, who generally express satisfication with their participation in the PHP.  The majority of PHPs are independent from state medical boards, although, depending on the state, impaired physicians who choose not to follow PHP recommendations may be reported to the state medical board given the potential impact on public health and patient safety.

(Choice A)  Asking partners about the cardiologist's home life is professionally inappropriate and intrusive.  Any suspected impairment should be formally investigated by the PHP, which can then implement steps for further evaluation and intervention as needed.

(Choice B)  Once signs of suspected impairment have been observed, the hospitalist is ethically obligated to report.  Waiting another month could potentially jeopardize patient safety and delay the opportunity for the cardiologist to receive needed treatment.

(Choices C and D)  To protect patient safety and prevent potential future errors, a report should be made to the PHP, regardless of whether other hospital staff members are concerned or official patient complaints have been filed.

Educational objective:
Physicians are ethically obligated to report suspected physician impairment to protect patient safety.  Physician Health Programs are organizations designated to investigate reported concerns and arrange for comprehensive assessment and treatment if necessary.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Physician misconduct

answerChoiceList.choice: Ask the cardiologist's partners if they are aware of any trouble he is experiencing at home
Continue monitoring the cardiologist's performance for another month prior to determining appropriate action
Inquire among hospital staff whether they are concerned about the cardiologist's behavior
Inquire if there are any patient complaints filed against the cardiologist related to patient care
Report the cardiologist to the hospital Physician Health Program

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Physician impairment and rehabilitation: reintegration into medical practice while ensuring patient safety: a position paper from the American College of Physicians.

questionList.questionText: A 79-year-old woman with advanced Alzheimer dementia is admitted to the intensive care unit due to somnolence, fever, and severe hypotension.  She lives in a skilled nursing home where she is bedbound and minimally verbal at baseline.  The patient has spent much of the past 2 years in the hospital due to frequent admissions for aspiration pneumonia, infected sacral pressure ulcers, and septic shock.  Broad-spectrum empiric antibiotics and intravenous fluids are begun.  The patient requires escalating doses of norepinephrine due to refractory hypotension.  Over the next 24 hours, she develops profound, anuric renal failure and increasing respiratory distress with diffuse crackles on examination, requiring significant supplemental oxygen.  The physician counsels the patient's family about her poor prognosis and presents the option of transitioning to comfort measures only.  Her eldest daughter, who speaks for the family, expresses reluctance, saying that "Every time Mom gets sick, all the doctors say she will die, but she always makes it.  We are not sure what to do, but we don't want to feel guilty for withdrawing care."  The patient's wishes are not specified on her health care advanced directive.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Care philosophies at the end of life

No escalation of treatment

Time-limited trial

Withdrawal of life support

  • Sets upper limits on treatment (eg, no invasive ventilation)
  • Avoids futile interventions with greatest morbidity
  • Provides intensive care for a predefined interval (eg, 2-3 days)
  • May entail temporary escalation, even if futile
  • Focuses completely on comfort measures only
  • Withdrawing life support ≠ "withdrawing care"

Creates time to process impending loss
& eases transition to withdrawal of life support

Active dying soon follows

This patient with advanced dementia and septic shock has deteriorated despite critical care measures (eg, vasopressor support).  She now has anuric renal failure with signs of edematous lung injury, signaling a grave prognosis.  Further escalation (eg, hemodialysis, mechanical ventilation) is unlikely to provide a significant benefit.

At end of life, families (or other surrogate decision-makers) often acknowledge the medical futility of aggressive treatment and embrace a transition to comfort-oriented care.  However, a few may view withdrawal of life support as "giving up" or hastening their loved one's demise.  In these challenging cases, it is often helpful to reframe the discussion around No Escalation of Treatment (NEOT) orders.

NEOT orders specify predetermined limits of treatment not to be exceeded, regardless of clinical deterioration.  Following family discussion, it may be agreed that interventions such as hemodialysis, mechanical ventilation, or invasive procedures will not be implemented.  NEOT orders often can prevent futile care while allowing time for the family to process their imminent loss, easing feelings of guilt that they may have accelerated the patient's death.

(Choice A)  When acting as surrogate decision-makers, families often can avoid feelings of guilt by making decisions that they know to be in line with what the patient would have wanted (ie, substituted judgment) and with shared familial/cultural values.  Simply advising them not to feel guilty is unlikely to be helpful.

(Choice B)  An ethics committee consultation is most helpful when there is intractable disagreement between the family and care team.  This patient's family is reluctant to withdraw care but is not in active conflict with the physician.  Candidly presenting the option of NEOT may help build agreement between the family and care team.

(Choice D)  The concept of quality of life is widely understood in a general sense.  However, its specific interpretation and application vary greatly between individuals, families, and cultural groups.  Although many families might judge this patient's quality of life as warranting withdrawal of aggressive measures, others could disagree and view such a statement from the physician as offensive.

(Choice E)  This patient's condition has deteriorated despite treatment, and further escalation is unlikely to provide a significant benefit.  Her family is reluctant to withdraw care but has not indicated a firm commitment to even more aggressive measures; a frank discussion with the family is warranted before any additional escalation in care.

Educational objective:
No Escalation of Treatment (NEOT) orders are predetermined limits of care that are not to be exceeded regardless of clinical status.  When a patient's family members are reluctant to withdraw care, NEOT orders can promote agreement with the care team, minimize futility, and lessen feelings of guilt for hastening the patient's death.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Medical futility

answerChoiceList.choice: Reassure the family that they should not feel guilty for withdrawing life support
Refer to the hospital ethics committee for guidance
Reframe the discussion to see if the family agrees to no escalation of treatment orders
Remind the family that aggressive care may be inappropriate given the patient's poor quality of life
Respect the family's wishes and continue to provide escalating care

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Easing the burden of surrogate decision making: the role of a do-not-escalate-treatment order.

questionList.questionText: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital for hematemesis.  The patient has had abdominal pain for the past 3 months and a 4.5 kg (10 lb) weight loss.  He has no other medical history and has not seen a physician in 30 years.  The patient is a retired car mechanic and lives with his wife; they attend church service every week.  After he is stabilized, an esophagogastroduodenoscopy is performed, which shows an ulcerated mass; biopsy confirms gastric adenocarcinoma.  When the physician approaches the patient to discuss the biopsy result, he is adamant that he does not want to know the result.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has gastric adenocarcinoma but declines to discuss the diagnosis.  Although patients have the right to know their diagnoses, they also may choose not to be informed of their medical information, including potentially life-threatening diagnoses.  Such refusal may be due to fear, avoidance, or cultural preferences.  Therefore, this patient's request to decline discussion of the biopsy result should be honored by the physician (Choices D and E).

However, relinquishing care (eg, discharging the patient) without a plan for communication risks discontinuity of information and suboptimal follow-up care.  In addition, deferring the disclosure to a consultant whose specialty (eg, medical oncology) would imply the diagnosis would be inappropriate and would violate the patient's right not to be informed (Choice C).  Instead, suitable next steps include:

  • Ask the patient to choose a family member or friend with whom the physician can disclose the diagnosis

  • Schedule a follow-up appointment with a primary care physician (PCP) and notify that physician of the patient's diagnosis and of the patient's decision not to be told the diagnosis

Should the patient change his mind, he can obtain information on his diagnosis from his family member and follow up with the PCP who can coordinate consultation with an oncologist.

(Choice B)  The patient's wife is his default surrogate decision-maker if he is incapacitated and unable to make decisions (and if he has not specified another decision-maker).  However, this patient has capacity to make his own decisions, including who should receive medical information on his behalf.  The physician should ask the patient to designate the person with whom to share the diagnosis.

Educational objective:
Patients have the right to know or to decline discussion of their diagnoses.  When a patient declines, the physician should ask the patient to choose a family member with whom the diagnosis can be disclosed; doing so ensures continuity of information should the patient choose to be informed later.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: End of life care

answerChoiceList.choice: Ask the patient whether there is a family member to whom the physician can disclose the diagnosis
Discuss the biopsy result with the patient's wife and allow her to make subsequent management decisions
Document that the patient does not wish to know the diagnosis and discharge the patient with an oncology appointment
Offer to have the patient's pastor or the hospital chaplain be present when the physician discusses the result
Warn the patient there is bad news, allow him time to mentally prepare, and set up a time tomorrow to discuss the result

questionMappingReferencesList.title: End-of-life care: guidelines for patient-centered communication.
The right to information.

questionList.questionText: A 65-year-old woman comes to the clinic due to markedly decreased urine output for the past 24 hours.  The patient underwent coronary angiography by the physician's colleague 5 days ago and was discharged the next day in stable condition.  Medical conditions include type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and coronary artery disease.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 140/92 mm Hg, pulse is 88/min, and respirations are 14/min.  Laboratory results show creatinine of 3.4 mg/dL and blood urea nitrogen of 40 mg/dL.  Acute tubular necrosis secondary to the contrast used during angiography is suspected.  Review of the medical chart before and after the procedure reveals that the patient did not receive adequate hydration prior to angiography.  The patient is very concerned and asks why she is unable to urinate.  Which of the following is the most appropriate response?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient likely has contrast-induced acute kidney injury (AKI), and her risk may have been unnecessarily increased due to lack of periprocedural intravenous hydration.  Discussing a potential medical mistake made by a colleague can be awkward, especially when the patient or family is pressing for detailed information.  Nevertheless, the physician should discuss the essential truth with the patient in a tactful and concise manner.

Ideally, patient discussions regarding an adverse outcome should be conducted by the physician who had primary responsibility for the initial intervention.  If the physician who performed the procedure is unavailable, a complete and detailed explanation may not be possible.  Therefore, a brief and honest explanation should be provided to the patient immediately ("This may be related to your recent angiography"), with the assurance that a definitive answer will be provided once the matter has been fully discussed with the colleague.  In the meantime, appropriate care and follow-up for the acute complication should be provided.

(Choice A)  AKI can be associated with administration intravenous contrast agents, and the risk may be greater in patients with diabetes mellitus.  However, this only increases the importance of proper care and does not excuse a serious medical mistake.

(Choice B)  This response completely evades the patient's direct question and is not appropriate.  Even though the physician has not had the opportunity to discuss the patient's care with the colleague, a brief acknowledgment of the potential relationship of the procedure to the complication should be made.

(Choice C)  Claiming that the cause of this patient's condition may never be known is deceptive, particularly since the sequence of events has a potentially clear explanation.  The physician should discuss the basic facts of the case in a tactful but honest way.

(Choice D)  Although intravenous hydration was not given prior to the procedure, additional information should be obtained from the responsible physician before determining that it was mistake; there might have been other reasons for not giving intravenous fluids.  Also, patients can develop AKI following intravenous contrast even with appropriate precautionary measures.

Educational objective:
Patient discussions regarding treatment complications should ideally be conducted by the physician who had primary responsibility for the initial intervention.  If that physician is unavailable, a brief and honest explanation should be provided to the patient by the covering physician, with the assurance that a definitive answer will be provided once the matter has been fully discussed with the colleague.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: "Given your underlying health conditions, this is unfortunately an expected event that occurs occasionally after angiography."
"Let me ask your regular physician to call you and discuss what might have happened."
"The cause of your condition is unlikely to ever be known, but let's focus on what we can do now with the best possible care."
"This complication could have been prevented if your physician had given intravenous hydration prior to the procedure.  Unfortunately, the physician forgot to do this."
"This may be related to your recent angiography, but I need to discuss it with your regular physician before I can give you a definitive answer."

questionList.questionText: As part of a quality improvement initiative, a hospital implements a new clinical decision support tool in the electronic medical record.  When a provider places a new medication order, the tool prompts the provider to confirm the order if a potentially dangerous multi-drug interaction exists, if a nonstandard dose is entered, or if the drug indication is missing.  A provider is reviewing medication orders on a patient with intractable colon cancer who is about to undergo partial colectomy.  The patient is currently taking oral morphine.  The provider discontinues oral morphine, determines an equivalent dose of intravenous hydromorphone, and enters the order into the electronic medical record.  Which of the following potential errors related to this order would the new clinical decision support tool be most likely to detect?
questionList.explanationText:
Clinical decision support systems

Purpose

  • Assist providers in making clinical decisions based on patient data (eg, laboratory data)
  • Usually integrated into computerized provider order systems
  • Recommend actions to providers based on patient clinical information

Potential benefits

  • Increase reliability of medical decision-making (ie, limiting potentially harmful variations of care)
  • Detect and intervene in cases of human error (eg, entering incorrect drug dose)
  • Reduce medication prescription errors

Examples

  • Tool suggesting default drug dose and frequency based on patient weight
  • Prompt recommending specific DVT prophylaxis in a patient following high-risk surgery
  • Prompt recommending specific diagnostic tests in a patient with suspected pulmonary embolism

DVT = deep venous thrombosis.

Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) describe processes that assist providers in making evidence-based diagnostic and therapeutic decisions.  Built into computerized provider order entry systems, CDSS prompt providers at the point-of-care (ie, upon entering an order) to consider specific actions based on patient data (eg, laboratory values, diagnoses).  CDSS can improve reliability (ie, reducing harmful variations in care) during complex decision-making processes (eg, diagnostic workup of pulmonary embolism).

CDSS can also reduce medication errors (ie, errors of drug selection, dosing, and administration).  When converting between opioids (eg, from oral morphine to intravenous hydromorphone, as in this patient), mathematical errors (eg, miscalculated dose) can occur and may be life-threatening (eg, 1 mg of intravenous hydrocodone is ~4 times as strong as 1 mg of intravenous morphine).  Because this CDSS is programmed to recognize nonstandard doses, it can alert providers to unusually high or low opioid doses, thereby preventing incorrect dosing related to mathematical errors.

(Choice A)  Drug monitoring errors occur when parameters related to high-risk medications are inadequately checked or acted upon (eg, not realizing that a patient with atrial fibrillation has a subtherapeutic INR value, which results in stroke).  Certain CDSS can reduce monitoring errors by reminding providers to check drug levels or act on abnormal results; however, such actions are not within the scope of the CDSS described in this scenario.

(Choices C and D)  Patient identification errors result in patients receiving an intervention intended for another patient (eg, wrong-patient surgery).  A mislabeling error is a type of patient identification error related to specimen labeling (eg, mislabeled patient blood resulting in transfusion reaction).  Prevention includes increasing redundancy, through use of dual identifiers (eg, medical record number and date of birth), and barcode scanning of patient wristband and specimen in addition to visual inspection.  This new CDSS is unlikely to prevent such errors.

Educational objective:
Clinical decision support systems (CDSS) assist providers in achieving reliability (minimizing harmful variations of care) and adhering to evidence-based guidelines in diagnostic and therapeutic processes.  CDSS can potentially reduce medication errors (eg, mathematical errors resulting from incorrect conversion of opioid equivalents).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Drug monitoring error
Mathematical error
Mislabeling error
Patient identification error

questionMappingReferencesList.title: An overview of clinical decision support systems: benefits, risks, and strategies for success.

questionList.questionText: A 7-year-old, previously healthy girl is brought to the office by her mother due to fever, sore throat, rhinorrhea, and cough for the past 3 days.  Temperature is 38.5 C (101.3 F), blood pressure is 104/68 mm Hg, and pulse is 125/min.  The patient seems uncomfortable but does not appear toxic.  She has mild erythema of the bilateral conjunctivae.  Oropharyngeal examination shows enlarged erythematous tonsils with exudates.  There is no lymphadenopathy.  The lungs are clear.  The abdomen is soft and no organomegaly is present.  Skin examination shows multiple linear ecchymoses localized symmetrically on the child's back.  The rest of the examination is unremarkable.  When asked about the skin findings, the mother states, "I have been rubbing her back with a coin to remove the illness; it is part of our culture."  In addition to providing appropriate care for the child's respiratory illness, which of the following is the best next step?
questionList.explanationText:
Providing culturally competent care is important in fostering trust with patients from diverse cultural and religious backgrounds.  These skills are developed through a genuine respect for patients' cultures and a willingness to incorporate them into individualized care plans.
