In this case, the patient's mother performs coining, a cultural practice originating from China and Southeast Asia.  A coin or another hard object is used to repeatedly stroke lubricated skin (eg, chest, back) in a linear, symmetric fashion.  The goal is to induce erythema (which later develops into ecchymoses) through which heat, negative energy, and illness are thought to be released from the body.  Another common cultural practice is cupping, in which a heated cup applied to the skin creates suction, resulting in circular ecchymoses.  These practices can be painful but usually carry little risk.

Parents should generally not be discouraged from coining, given its cultural roots and limited adverse effects.  In addition, parents should not be accused of child abuse or reported to authorities because, within the Asian culture, the intention of coining is to alleviate illness (ie, not to harm the child) (Choices A and D).  Further management may include offering less painful alternatives (eg, ibuprofen for fever, antibiotics if indicated).

(Choice C)  Ecchymoses limited to traumatized areas are not concerning for a platelet disorder or coagulopathy.  In contrast, bruising in nontraumatized areas, hepatosplenomegaly, and/or lymphadenopathy not otherwise explained by an acute illness, none of which are seen in this patient, should prompt evaluation for hematologic disorders (eg, complete blood count, coagulation studies).  Patients who have a bleeding disorder are generally discouraged from practices such as coining due to risk for bleeding.

Educational objective:
In coining, a practice from China and Southeast Asia, a coin is rubbed on the body, producing linear erythema and ecchymoses.  Thought to alleviate illness and fever, it is usually safe.  To provide culturally sensitive care, physicians should not discourage patients from the practice or report them for misperceived abuse.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Cultural considerations

answerChoiceList.choice: Advise the mother regarding the legal consequences of this practice
No additional intervention needed
Perform complete blood count and coagulation testing
Report to child protective services

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Coining: an ancient treatment widely practiced among Asians.

questionList.questionText: A 16-year-old boy is brought to the office by his mother for follow-up after sustaining a ligament injury while playing football 4 weeks ago.  The patient has been using a splint and going to physical therapy twice weekly.  His pain has decreased, and he is hoping to return to football practice.  Medical history is significant for asthma managed with as-needed albuterol and prior treatment of gonorrhea, which he acquired a year earlier after an unprotected sexual encounter.  Physical examination of the ankle reveals no pain, tenderness, or swelling and there is full range of motion.  At the end of the visit the mother mentions that the family is moving to a new neighborhood and will be changing medical providers.  She asks for a copy of her son's medical record to take to the new practice.  Which of the following is the best response to the mother's request?
questionList.explanationText:
Protecting adolescent confidentiality is critical to maintaining open communication between the patient and physician regarding sensitive issues (eg, sexuality, mental health, substance use) and can significantly impact an adolescent's willingness to seek future health care.  Adolescents have the right to consent for treatment of sexually transmitted infections (STIs), and this information is considered confidential.

In this situation, transfer of the medical record to the parent may inadvertently violate the patient's confidentiality regarding his treatment for gonorrhea.  Rather than providing a copy to the parent, the patient's medical record can be transferred directly to the new provider.  In this way, the mother's desire to ensure continuity of care is respected and the patient's confidentiality is not compromised.

(Choices A and B)  Although the medical record is the property of the clinic, it is in the best interest of the patient to share information with new providers or specialists and inappropriate to decline the parent's request.  The adolescent's confidentiality can be maintained by having the medical record transferred directly to the new provider.

(Choice D)  Although redacting the record is a possibility, the mother has requested a copy of the record to facilitate continuity of care.  Providing her with only nonconfidential information would maintain confidentiality but fail to adequately ensure continuity regarding the entirety of the patient's treatment history.

(Choice E)  The mother does not have the right to the patient's entire medical record because confidentiality regarding treatment of STIs should be maintained.

Educational objective:
Adolescent confidentiality regarding sensitive issues, including treatment for sexually transmitted infections, mental health concerns, and substance use, should be protected.  When transferring care, it is preferable to provide the medical record directly to the new provider rather than providing a copy to the parent.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Patient confidentiality

answerChoiceList.choice: Decline to provide the medical record but offer to exchange information verbally with the new provider
Explain to the mother that you are unable to provide the medical record because it is the legal property of the clinic
Inform the mother that you will transfer the medical records directly to the new provider
Provide only nonconfidential information to the mother
Provide the entire medical record to the mother because she has a legal right to it

questionMappingReferencesList.title: I thought you said this was confidential?-challenges to protecting privacy for teens and young adults.
Sexually transmitted infections in adolescents.
Confidentiality, consent, and caring for the adolescent patient.

questionList.questionText: An 83-year-old woman comes to the office due to chronic kidney disease.  Laboratory results show an estimated glomerular filtration rate of 18 mL/min/1.73 m2.  Medical history includes hypertension, coronary artery disease, and osteoporosis.  Five years ago, the patient had a right hip fracture due to a fall in her home after she rose too quickly.  She can perform activities of daily living and lives with her husband, who is in good health.  Blood pressure is 130/79 mm Hg and pulse is 86/min.  On examination, the patient is alert.  The lungs sound clear without crackles.  There is 2+ bilateral pedal edema.  The patient can ambulate slowly with a walker.  She asks, "My cardiologist says my heart is stable, but my kidneys are getting worse, and I'll probably need dialysis soon.  What are your thoughts on dialysis?"  Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the physician?
questionList.explanationText:
End-stage renal disease (ESRD) is imminent in this elderly patient with significant comorbidities and functional decline.  The next steps involve counseling the patient on the benefits and risks of treatment options (ie, dialysis vs nondialytic conservative kidney care) and ascertaining her goals of care.

Although dialysis extends life expectancy in younger patients with limited comorbidity, that benefit becomes negligible in elderly patients with significant comorbidity and functional decline.  In addition, obtaining vascular access and devoting time and transportation for dialysis increase discomfort and time away from family.  Unlike younger patients, elderly patients tend to have prolonged fatigue and increased hospitalizations (eg, catheter-related infections) when undergoing either peritoneal dialysis or hemodialysis, which diminishes quality of life (Choices B and C).

Alternately, conservative kidney care is a nondialytic option that focuses on patient comfort and is preferred for elderly patients and/or those with advanced comorbidities (Choice E).  In this option, diet (eg, low sodium, low potassium, relatively low protein to minimize acid accumulation) and medications (eg, phosphate binder, erythropoiesis-stimulating agents) are used to ameliorate volume, electrolyte, and acid/base disturbances, as well as anemia and hypertension.  Symptoms of fatigue, nausea, and pain associated with ESRD are also addressed.  When patients elect to not initiate dialysis, the average life expectancy while on conservative kidney care is 6 months to 2 years.

(Choice D)  Because this patient specifically asked about dialysis, it is best for the physician to explain its benefits and risks rather than independently eliminating it on behalf of the patient.

Educational objective:
In elderly patients with end-stage renal disease, especially those with advanced comorbidities and functional decline, chronic dialysis does not significantly extend life expectancy when compared to conservative kidney care; it is associated with increased hospitalizations and diminished quality of life.  These factors should be discussed prior to initiation of dialysis.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: End of life care

answerChoiceList.choice: "Although dialysis has its benefits, I would like to discuss the risks associated with it."
"Dialysis, especially home peritoneal dialysis, will allow you to avoid frequent hospitalizations.  I recommend it."
"Dialysis will allow you to live longer with good quality of life.  I recommend it."
"I do not recommend dialysis given your age, so let's talk about other options that I think are better."
"Without dialysis, most patients die quickly.  We do not have much choice other than initiating dialysis."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: End-stage renal disease: medical management.
End-stage renal disease: symptom management and advance care planning.

questionList.questionText: A survey is conducted among medical residents at a busy academic medical center to assess resident experiences regarding handoff errors.  The survey finds that 87% of residents report at least 1 adverse event affecting patient care due to inadequate handoffs; these adverse events are most common between 11:00 PM and 5:00 AM, when a cross-covering resident manages care of patients belonging to multiple primary teams.  In addition to system-level strategies, which of the following practices is most effective in reducing the risk for adverse events resulting from verbal handoffs?
questionList.explanationText:
Reducing errors in patient handoffs

Optimize
information

  • Discuss highest-acuity (ie, "sickest") patients first
  • Provide extra detail on critical patients
  • Avoid information overload

Optimize
communication

  • Follow template (eg, checklist)
  • Include oral & written communication
  • Encourage questions throughout discussion
  • Use read-back selectively (eg, for to-do items)

Optimize
actions

  • Include follow-up items (eg, to-do list)
  • Provide anticipatory guidance (eg, "if/then" format)

Handoffs (also called sign-outs) involve oral and written information exchange to facilitate the transfer of patient care (eg, from primary team to cross-covering resident or new service).  Handoffs increase the risk for communication errors and patient adverse events; such errors are more common when handoffs involve many patients or multiple high-acuity patients.

Handoffs necessitate communicating a large amount of information in limited time.  Errors can be reduced by prioritizing information, which reduces information overload.  Communication should focus first on the most severely ill patients who have the highest risk for complications or unforeseen clinical deterioration (eg, diabetic ketoacidosis, high-risk labor and delivery).  For these patients, information on daily clinical progress and baseline clinical status should be communicated at the beginning of the handoff, along with clear anticipatory guidance (eg, "if/then" instructions regarding possible clinical scenarios).

The following are additional best practices for handoffs:

  • Follow a structured format (eg, checklist) to ensure that basic information (eg, code status) is consistently covered.

  • Adopt an interactive approach, encouraging the receiver to ask questions and clarify items throughout the discussion, rather than only at the end, which increases the risk of rushing or forgetting questions (Choice A).

  • Perform selective read-back (ie, closed-loop communication in which the receiver repeats back the information to ensure accurate comprehension) of the most critical information.

(Choice C)  Note-taking should be encouraged during the discussion; it can emphasize and help reinforce important information exchanged during the hand-off.

(Choice D)  Although handoffs should include additional details (eg, overview of clinical course, baseline status) relating to critically ill patients, providing exhaustive details on all aspects of the clinical care for every patient is not recommended because this can lead to information overload and overwhelm the receiver.

Educational objective:
Verbal handoffs during transfers of care necessitate exchanging a large amount of information in a limited time.  To minimize communication errors, handoff discussions should prioritize patients with highest medical acuity, confirm accurate comprehension of critical information (eg, selective read-back), and follow a structured and interactive approach.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Encourage questions only at the end of the handoff discussion
Focus on the most severely ill patients at the beginning of the handoff
Discourage note-taking during the discussion to increase attentiveness
Provide exhaustive details on all aspects of the clinical care for every patient

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Interns overestimate the effectiveness of their hand-off communication.
Physician handoffs: opportunities and limitations for supportive technologies.

questionList.questionText: A 45-year-old man is seen in the clinic for follow-up of type 2 diabetes mellitus.  He has attempted treatment with multiple oral agents but has experienced frequent hypoglycemia, and his glucose levels have remained uncontrolled.  The physician prescribes a new, long-acting injectable antidiabetic drug that has a different mechanism of action than previous medications and does not cause hypoglycemia.  However, 2 weeks later, the patient calls to report that his insurance company denied coverage because the medication was deemed medically unnecessary.  Which of the following is the best next step by the physician?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient has uncontrolled type 2 diabetes mellitus and attempts at management with oral agents have led to frequent hypoglycemia.  The physician prescribed a new, injectable medication that has a low risk of hypoglycemia (eg, GLP-1 agonist); however, the patient's insurance company denied coverage.  Because the physician believes that this medication is appropriate therapy for this patient's condition, the physician should contact the insurance company to request escalated review.

Most insurance plans maintain hierarchical lists of medications based on cost-effectiveness to determine coverage.  Preferred medications with the lowest cost and highest effectiveness (eg, metformin) are typically automatically approved for coverage; in contrast, medications that are more expensive (eg, nongeneric medication) or have elevated risk of adverse effects may require a higher patient cost share (eg, copay) or be denied coverage.

However, patients sometimes require these nonpreferred medications.  To address such circumstances, insurance plans maintain an appeal process (often termed prior authorization) in which a treating physician can request review from a physician (sometimes designated as a medical director or physician reviewer) or other qualified person (eg, pharmacist) who can review the patient's case and verify the appropriate need for the medication.

(Choice B)  The initial appeal is best requested by the physician who understands the medical rationale for the requested medication.  Placing the burden of appeal on the patient is less likely to be successful and increases the likelihood of inadequate treatment.

(Choice C)  If the insurance plan denies coverage following review, the patient may need to pay the full cost out of pocket.  However, the physician should first appeal for higher-level review.

(Choice D)  Patients who cannot afford their medication often can obtain medications at discounted rates through charitable organizations or directly from the manufacturer through a discount program.  However, these options are not necessary if the drug is approved following insurance review.

(Choice E)  Medication samples are primarily intended to allow patients to quickly test new medications for effectiveness and tolerability.  However, samples are not a dependable source of medication and should not be relied on as a patient's primary means of obtaining medication.

Educational objective:
Insurance plans may deny coverage of medications that are less cost-effective or carry higher risk than the preferred medication choices.  When a treating physician believes a denied medication is appropriate therapy for a patient, the physician should request escalated review (eg, prior authorization) for coverage by the plan.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Health insurance

answerChoiceList.choice: Contact the insurance company to request medical director review
Counsel the patient to file an appeal with his insurance company
Explain that the patient must pay out-of-pocket for the medication
Refer the patient to a social worker to explore medication discount options
Request medication samples for the patient from the drug company

questionList.questionText: A 35-year-old man comes to the office for a preventive examination.  Medical history includes asthma.  The patient has smoked for the past 20 years; he tried quitting 3 years ago on his own but was unsuccessful because he felt very jittery without cigarettes and restarted smoking to relieve the symptoms.  The patient is hesitant to attempt smoking cessation again because he does not want to relapse and "be seen as a failure."  Which of the following is the best response to this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient is not ready to stop smoking.  However, his previous attempt indicates that he is aware of the benefits of smoking cessation and is likely motivated to quit.

Behavioral therapy combined with pharmacotherapy is the most effective strategy for smoking cessation.  Behavioral therapy should address the patient's motivations and barriers to quitting.  This patient's main barrier is nicotine withdrawal symptoms (eg, marked jitteriness), which are likely to benefit from both pharmacotherapy and possibly behavioral therapy interventions.

Supportive therapy is an effective approach for smoking cessation and can easily be provided in a routine office visit.  Supportive therapy provides encouragement to the patient and often includes the following:

  • Education about the process of quitting (eg, selecting a quit day, choice of pharmacotherapy)
  • Reminder that initial failure is common, and patients may require several attempts before achieving long-term success
  • Reassurance that over half of smokers can eventually achieve long-term abstinence

(Choices A and D)  Telling patients "Don't worry" or to "forget" about difficulties may be seen as dismissive and misses the opportunity to address the patient's primary barrier to cessation (ie, withdrawal symptoms).

(Choice B)  Telling the patient that he is "not trying hard enough" is likely to be viewed as unempathetic, and may feed into the patient's fear that smoking relapse may be seen by others as a personal failure.

(Choice C)  Passively waiting to address smoking cessation until the patient brings it up is not recommended, even if he had an unsuccessful attempt in the past.  The physician should encourage cessation at every visit, rather than waiting for the patient to initiate the discussion.

Educational objective:
Smoking cessation failure is common, and patients may require several attempts before achieving long-term success.  However, patients should be reassured that over half of smokers eventually can achieve long-term abstinence.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Smoking Cessation

answerChoiceList.choice: "Don't worry about feeling jittery, it's normal—almost everyone who tries quitting experiences it."
"I have patients who have quit that have smoked longer than you; I don't think you are trying hard enough."
"I know that failure can hurt—let me know when you are ready to try again."
"I would like you to forget your old fears and concentrate on quitting."
"Over half of smokers eventually quit successfully, but it may take several attempts."

questionList.questionText: A physician-researcher at an academic institution is planning to study the effectiveness of a novel nerve stimulator device for chronic pain.  The device will be tested as part of a large double-blinded, randomized clinical trial.  The trial is funded partially by the device manufacturer as well as by grants from the federal government, which has identified nonpharmaceutical management of chronic pain as a high national research priority.  The researcher has previously received payments from the device manufacturer for lectures about the device given at national conferences.  The physician and support staff from the institution will be responsible for study design and implementation, and an academic researcher and biostatistician from the manufacturing company will oversee analysis of study results.  Which of the following best describes the potential for conflict of interest (COI) generated by the manufacturer's involvement in the research?
questionList.explanationText:
Conflict of interest (COI) in clinical research can create an unconscious, favorable bias toward the investigational product (ie, drug or device being studied), compromising the validity of the results.  Common sources of COI include the following:

  • Financial incentives (eg, stocks, speaking fees) to the investigator that are influenced by the study results or financial success of the investigational product

  • Using industry-sponsored personnel (eg, statistician) in study design or data analysis

Industry sponsorship of clinical research to cover investigator salaries and project expenses is common and alone does not constitute COI.  However, factors in this case that may lead to COI include additional financial incentives to the investigator (eg, speaking fees) and use of industry-sponsored personnel in data analysis (Choice E).

To address these COIs, the institutional review board (IRB), a regulatory body that oversees clinical research, will likely require the investigator to disclose financial incentives to research subjects and analyze the research data by an independent analysis team before it approves the study.  Ultimately, it is the responsibility of the principal investigator to comply with the recommendations from the IRB to mitigate or eliminate COI.

(Choice A)  Disclosure of the investigator's financial compensation to potential subjects is appropriate but does not sufficiently mitigate this study's COI.  The use of the manufacturer's personnel to analyze study results is highly likely to bias study results and should be avoided.

(Choice C)  The magnitude of potential public benefit may influence availability of federal grants for clinical research but does not address COI.  Rather, mitigation of COI in research is often required for continued funding of federal research.

(Choice D)  Randomization and blinding can reduce bias in the data generated by the investigator during the trial.  However, study design alone does not adequately mitigate bias introduced by use of industry-sponsored employees in data analysis.

Educational objective:
Incentivizing researchers based on product success and employing industry-sponsored personnel in data analysis generate conflict of interest (COI), which can compromise study results by creating a bias favoring the product under investigation.  These COIs must be mitigated or eliminated before a study is approved by the institutional review board.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Research ethics

answerChoiceList.choice: COI is likely present and can be sufficiently addressed by disclosing financial relationships to the subjects
COI is likely present, and the proposed study should not proceed under these terms due to high risk of bias
COI is likely present but permissible because the research has significant potential to improve public welfare
COI is likely present but will not affect research integrity because the trial is double-blinded and randomized
COI is not likely present because the study is also supported by federal grants

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Institutional review boards: purpose and challenges.

questionList.questionText: A 27-year-old woman is admitted to the hospital for evaluation of abdominal pain that has intensified over the past 3 months.  She describes the pain as severe and has been unable to work due to her symptoms.  Medical history includes lower back pain, irregular menstrual cycle, depression, and borderline personality disorder.  The admitting senior resident physician obtains a detailed history, after which the patient remarks, "You're a great doctor, and I can tell you really understand what I'm going through."  Vital signs are stable.  Physical examination shows mild, diffuse abdominal tenderness and is otherwise unremarkable.  The next day, the patient is seen by the first-year resident physician who explains her role on the treatment team.  She performs a brief physical examination, explains that an abdominal CT scan and laboratory tests have been ordered, and offers to answer any questions.  The patient refuses to undergo testing and angrily says, "You're not good at your job.  I know a good doctor when I see one.  You just order tests without even knowing anything about me."  Which of the following is the most appropriate response by the resident?
questionList.explanationText:
Patients with personality disorders often display challenging behaviors, which can result in problematic interactions with providers and negatively impact care (eg, patient distrust and refusal of recommended treatments, demands for special treatment).  Patients with borderline personality disorder frequently use the defense mechanism of splitting, in which they experience the self or others in extremes, either all positive or all negative.

This patient's polarized views of the admitting senior resident as "good" (eg, "You're a great doctor") and the first-year resident as "bad" (eg, "You're not good at your job") has led to an impasse in treatment and potential division within the treatment team.  The optimal approach to manage splitting in the inpatient setting is for all providers to see the patient jointly as a team.  This allows the team to present a united front, providing clear and consistent information, preventing miscommunication, and minimizing the potential for splitting to divide the team or interfere with treatment.

(Choice A)  The first-year resident's assurance that the tests are indicated is unlikely to defuse the patient's anger and elicit her cooperation because she already perceives this physician as incompetent and "bad."

(Choice B)  This statement is defensive, and having the perceived "bad" team member tell the patient that her chart has been reviewed is unlikely to reassure her or reduce splitting.  Arranging a team meeting with all members present would be more helpful.

(Choice C)  Promising to spend more time with the patient after the tests are completed does not address her accusation that these tests were ordered without the resident knowing anything about her.  It would not help to reduce the patient's tendency to split the team.

Educational objective:
Patients with borderline personality disorder use the defense mechanism of splitting, which can result in polarized views of team members as "good" and "bad" and create division within the treatment team.  Seeing the patient jointly as a team can help provide clear and consistent information and minimize the tendency for splitting to interfere with treatment.
questionList.subject: Psychiatry
questionList.title: Personality disorders

answerChoiceList.choice: "I can see that you are upset; but I can assure you that we just don't order tests for no reason."
"I know I am good at my job.  I can assure you that I have carefully reviewed your chart."
"I would be happy to spend more time with you after your test results are complete."
"Let me come back with our team and we can review your treatment plan together."

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Social cognition and borderline personality disorder: splitting and trust impairment findings.
Borderline personality disorder.
Difficult physician-patient encounters.

questionList.questionText:
The following vignette applies to the next 2 items.  The items in the set must be answered in sequential order.  Once you click Proceed to Next Item, you will not be able to add or change an answer.

The medical director of a busy primary care clinic is leading a quality-improvement project aimed at reducing the patient no-show rate.  The director is planning to implement a telephone and text-messaging reminder service that sends a message to patients 1 day prior to their appointment, prompting them to confirm their appointment or reschedule.

Item 1 of 2

Which of the following quality-improvement strategies is best suited to systematically assess this reminder system's effectiveness on no-show rates?
questionList.explanationText:
A run chart is a longitudinal graph that tracks a process performance outcome (eg, patient no-show rates, a metric of patient follow-up and scheduling efficiency) over time.  Run charts are frequently used to:

  • Visually identify performance variations, including trends, defined as a consistent directional change (eg, increase or decrease) for ≥5 consecutive points

  • Assess effectiveness of a quality improvement intervention by comparing changes in process outcomes pre- and post-intervention

A run chart is appropriate for assessing this reminder system's potential effectiveness in improving no-show rates.  Assuming absence of other concurrent interventions, a downward trend in no-show rates following implementation suggests that the system likely helped reduce no-show rates.

(Choice A)  A near-miss analysis is used following a "close call," an event that could have resulted in patient harm but was prevented in time, such as when an incorrect medication dose is ordered for a patient, but the error is detected by the nurse before administration.

(Choice C)  Staff and patient surveys may provide useful information on reminder system acceptability; however, run charts offer superior assessment of system effectiveness because they directly track the outcome of interest (no-show rate).

(Choice D)  Failure modes and effects analysis (FMEA) is a prospective quality improvement tool in which an error-prone process (eg, central line insertion) is analyzed to determine all mechanisms, or "modes" (eg, incorrect sterile procedure), causing error (eg, infections).  FMEA would not provide useful information on no-show rates or the reminder system's effectiveness.

Educational objective:
A run chart is a quality improvement tool that graphs a process performance outcome (eg, no-show rate) over time (eg, before and after a quality improvement intervention).  Run charts allow visualization of trends (≥5 consecutive points with consistent directional change) and systematically determines effectiveness of a quality improvement intervention.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Healthcare quality

answerChoiceList.choice: Conducting a near-miss analysis after system implementation
Constructing a run chart analyzing longitudinal trends
Distributing patient and staff surveys pre- and post-system implementation
Performing a failure modes and effects analysis

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Prevalence, predictors, and economic consequences of no-shows.

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

The medical director tracks monthly no-show rates for 18 months following implementation of the reminder system.  A run chart is constructed comparing no-show rates prior to and following system implementation, as shown below.  Which of the following conclusions is most closely supported by the trends seen in the run chart?
questionList.explanationText:
Run charts, a graph of an outcome of interest (eg, no-show rates) over time, are often used to assess effectiveness of a quality improvement intervention (eg, reminder system).  This run chart suggests that the reminder system was partially effective in reducing no-show rates:

  • Prior to the intervention, no-show rates are unacceptably high for all data points (ie, markedly above goal rate of 10%).

  • Following the intervention, no-show rates follow a downward trend, with consistently decreasing no-show rates from months June to October (ie, for ≥5 consecutive points) (Choice B).

  • No show-rates meet or perform better than the goal at several instances.

However, the run chart also indicates that the reminder system has not consistently achieved sufficient no-show reductions.  For example, no-show rates are still unacceptably high during certain months (eg, November, December) (Choice A).

Therefore, based on the run chart's findings, the reminder system likely addresses some factors reducing patient follow-up (eg, patient forgetting appointment) but not others (eg, seasonal travel for end-of-year holidays).

(Choice D)  The graph shows a consistent downward trend in post-system no-show rates that was absent pre-intervention, suggesting that no-show rates were influenced by the system (rather than being independent).

(Choice E)  The decreasing trend in no-show rates following implementation supports the system's partial effectiveness in reducing no-show rates.

Educational objective:
Run charts enable systematic assessment of an intervention's effect on process performance (eg, no-show rate).  Presence of a desired trend (ie, consistent directional change for 5 or more data points in a row) post-intervention suggests potential effectiveness; persistent underperformance or excessive variation suggests the intervention only partially addresses factors influencing performance.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Healthcare quality

answerChoiceList.choice: The reminder system caused sufficient improvement in patient follow-up rates
The reminder system failed to produce meaningful improvements in patient follow-up
The reminder system addresses some, but not all, causes of low patient follow-up
Patient follow-up outcomes appear independent of reminder system effects
Potential effectiveness of the reminder system cannot be determined by the data shown

questionList.questionText: A 70-year-old woman comes to the office as a new patient to establish care.  The patient has no acute concerns.  She has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus well controlled with metformin and has been taking aspirin, a beta blocker, an ACE inhibitor, and a statin since sustaining a myocardial infarction 2 years earlier.  The patient lives alone in a one-story apartment and is independent with her activities of daily living.  She consumes 1 glass of wine 6 days a week, walks her dog for 15 minutes every morning, and eats a well-balanced diet.  Temperature is 36.9 C (98.4 F), blood pressure is 129/78 mm Hg without orthostatic changes, and pulse is 64/min.  BMI is 20 kg/m2.  On physical examination, the patient is alert, conversant, and fully oriented.  When asked to rise from a chair and walk, she pushes with her arms for support when rising and is able to walk briskly to the end of the room without ataxia.  Which of the following strategies is most effective to reduce this patient's risk of falls?
questionList.explanationText:
Falls in older adults

Overview

  • Leading cause of injury, morbidity, mortality

Risk factors

  • History of fall
  • Sensory & cognitive disturbance
  • Chronic disease (eg, T2DM, arthritis, CVD)
  • Medications (eg, neuroleptics, antidepressants, vasodilators)

Outpatient prevention

  • Screening: musculoskeletal (eg, "get up & go" test*), vision, hearing, bone density, orthostasis
  • Medication & home safety review
  • Correction of vitamin D deficiency (in select patients)
  • Supervised exercise program

Inpatient prevention

  • Assess fall risk & customize strategies to patient's specific risk factors
  • Optimize environment (eg, minimize furniture, lower the bed, place in direct view of nurses if high risk)
  • Perform frequent checks on high-risk patients
  • Avoid restraints & overreliance on fall alert systems

*Ask the patient to rise from a chair & walk briskly to the end of the room.  Time & patient difficulty in this test predict the risk of falling.

CVD = cardiovascular disease; T2DM = type 2 diabetes mellitus.

Falls are a leading cause of morbidity in older adults, increasing the risk for prolonged immobilization, severe injury (eg, hip fracture) and functional decline.  Because several risk factors for falls (eg, weakness, vision impairment, unnecessary medications) are modifiable, clinicians should regularly assess fall risk (eg, testing mobility, strength, vision, hearing) and implement strategies to prevent falls.

This patient has not previously fallen but does have a history of chronic disease (eg, coronary artery disease, type 2 diabetes mellitus), which constitutes a fall risk factor.  Moreover, she demonstrates some difficulty rising from a chair (eg, needing to push with arms for support), an indicator of gait and muscle imbalance that can contribute to increased fall risk.

Supervised exercise training has been shown to significantly reduce fall risk and should be recommended for all elderly patients who are at high risk for falls (or who have sustained a fall previously).  The program should include strength, balance (eg, Tai Chi), and cardiovascular components (eg, walking).  Therefore, even though this patient currently walks regularly, she would benefit from supervised exercises to build strength.

(Choice A)  Vitamin D supplementation is recommended to prevent falls only for individuals who are known to have vitamin D insufficiency (<10 ng/mL) or who have had previous falls.  In contrast, Vitamin D has not been shown to reduce fall incidence in older patients without these conditions (eg, this patient).

(Choice C)  Excessive doses of certain antihypertensive medications (eg, calcium channel blockers, diuretics) may increase fall risk.  However, when prescribed at appropriate doses in patients without orthostasis, antihypertensives do not significantly increase fall risk.  This patient does not have orthostatic changes, and tapering off the ACE inhibitor is not recommended given her history of myocardial infarction.

(Choice D)  Patients should receive education on fall prevention strategies; however, this is less effective than exercise training in reducing incidence of falls.

(Choice E)  Alcohol consumption within recommended limits (eg, 1 drink or less per day in women or 2 drinks or less per day in men) is not associated with increased risk of falls.

Educational objective:
Fall risk should be regularly assessed in older patients; chronic disease and muscle weakness (eg, difficulty rising from a chair) are associated with increased fall risk.  Supervised exercise training is recommended for all older patients with high fall risk and should include strength, cardiovascular, and balance components.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Falls

answerChoiceList.choice: Empiric supplementation with vitamin D
Enrollment in a supervised strength training program
Initiating slow taper off ACE inhibitor
Patient handout describing evidence-based fall prevention strategies
Reduction in alcohol intake

questionMappingReferencesList.title: The effect of fall prevention exercise programmes on fall induced injuries in community dwelling older adults: systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials.
Interventions to prevent falls in older adults: updated evidence report and systematic review for the US Preventive Services Task Force.

questionList.questionText: As part of a new patient safety initiative to deliver high-value care, the director of an intensive care unit at a teaching hospital implements interprofessional team-based rounding.  Daily patient rounds are conducted by a team that includes the attending physician, a pharmacist, a social worker, a nurse practitioner, and a case manager.  Which of the following is most likely to promote highly effective functioning within this structure?
questionList.explanationText:
Features of effective teams* in health care

Safety culture

  • Resource commitment to safety

Collaboration

  • Shared understanding & prioritization of goals
  • Distinct roles that avoid a steep hierarchy

Psychologic safety

  • Asking questions & voicing concerns encouraged
  • Avoiding blame or retaliation

Responsiveness

  • Feedback respected & promptly acted on

Situational awareness

  • Persistent mindfulness & safety vigilance
  • Cross-checking of each other's actions

Transparency

  • Prompt disclosure of errors & safety information

*Poor teamwork is a leading root cause of sentinel events; improved communication reduces medical errors & improves patient/clinical outcomes.

Teamwork promotes safety in high-risk, complex environments such as health care.  Conducting rounds with interprofessional or interdisciplinary (ie, involving multiple health professions or disciplines) teams can prevent medical errors by improving communication and coordination of patient care activities.

Effective team functioning is promoted by ensuring that all members have a shared understanding of goals (eg, overall goals for hospitalization, immediate clinical priorities in patient care, planned studies or procedures).  Teams with this shared understanding are significantly more effective in achieving intended outcomes (eg, comprehensive assessment of patient clinical status, completion of necessary patient care tasks).

Additional characteristics of effective teams include:

  • Clear and unique (rather than overlapping) roles, which reduces unnecessary and potentially harmful duplication of effort (eg, multiple providers administering insulin to a patient) (Choice D)

  • Roles that are commensurate to each team member's skills, knowledge, training, and experience.  For example, although involvement of all interprofessional team members is needed to promote optimal patient care, some patient care goals (eg, assessment of overall clinical status or complex management decisions) require more extensive participation by members of specific disciplines (eg, nurse, physician) (Choice C)

  • Psychological safety (ie, concerns can be freely expressed without fear or intimidation) and absence of excessive hierarchy (ie, steep differences in authority levels between team members)

(Choice B)  Team efficiency is essential but should not be prioritized over achievement of team goals (eg, patient safety, addressing unexpected medical conditions).  For example, additional time spent on rounding is sometimes necessary to improve coordination of care and prevent errors.

Educational objective:
Teamwork reduces error in complex health care settings.  Effective teams are characterized by a shared understanding of goals, clear roles based on knowledge and skills (rather than authority), and psychological safety (ie, comfort in expressing concerns).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Healthcare quality

answerChoiceList.choice: Ensuring that all team members have a similar understanding of desired goals
Prioritizing completion of team activities in the shortest amount of time
Promoting equal participation in patient care activities by each health discipline represented
Reducing team hierarchy and promoting overlap of roles among team members

questionList.questionText: A 78-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by ambulance after developing right-sided hemiplegia and dysarthria while at a restaurant with his wife an hour earlier. He is currently undergoing chemotherapy for metastatic lung cancer.  Temperature is 37 C (98.6 F), blood pressure is 160/86 mm Hg, pulse is 90/min, and respirations are 16/min.  The patient is alert, but his speech is garbled and incoherent and he does not follow commands.  His right side has 2/5 strength.  Fingerstick glucose is 88 mg/dL.  CT of the head shows no hemorrhage, and the patient has no contraindications to intravenous thrombolysis.  His wife arrives at the bedside and says, "He has a DNR.  He has an advanced directive that says he does not want to be resuscitated."  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management of this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
This patient with an acute ischemic stroke is a candidate for intravenous thrombolysis but has an advance directive specifying he does not want to be resuscitated.  A "do not resuscitate" (DNR) order specifically prohibits cardiopulmonary resuscitation (eg, chest compressions, defibrillation) in the event of cardiopulmonary arrest.  However, it does not mean "do not treat" and does not prohibit other therapeutic interventions (eg, thrombolysis) that may be needed to address concurrent or newly presenting conditions as determined by standard practice (Choice C).

In this scenario, the patient should be offered thrombolysis according to current standards of care for treating acute ischemic stroke.  However, his incoherent speech and inability to follow commands render him unable to make an informed medical decision regarding a treatment plan.  Therefore, the most appropriate next step is to provide the relevant medical information to the patient's wife, the presumed substitute decision maker, and administer intravenous thrombolysis with her consent.

If he develops cardiopulmonary arrest at any time (eg, following thrombolysis, during hospitalization), the DNR order should be honored.

(Choice B)  Competency is a legal determination (made by a judge) about a patient's global decision-making ability.  In contrast, capacity is a clinical determination (made by a physician) about a patient's ability to make a specific medical decision at a specific moment in time.  Capacity, not competency, is determined when obtaining informed consent.

(Choice D)  This patient with acute ischemic stroke and disabling neurological deficits (eg, aphasia, hemiplegia) should be offered intravenous thrombolysis according to current standards of care.  His DNR order is not relevant since he is not in cardiopulmonary arrest, and a potentially terminal illness (eg, metastatic cancer) does not prohibit providing a therapeutic intervention (eg, thrombolysis for stroke) that will significantly impact his quality of life.

Educational objective:
A "do not resuscitate" (DNR) order applies only to cardiopulmonary arrest.  Patients with a DNR order should continue to receive treatment consistent with the current standards of the care for their presenting condition (eg, intravenous thrombolysis for stroke).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Do not resuscitate

answerChoiceList.choice: Administer intravenous thrombolysis with his wife's consent
Determine whether the patient has the competency to agree to further interventions
Withhold intravenous thrombolysis because of his advanced directive
Withhold intravenous thrombolysis because of his metastatic cancer and advanced directive

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Perceptions of care following initiation of do-not-resuscitate orders.
The impact of do-not-resuscitate order in the emergency department on respiratory failure after ICU admission.

questionList.questionText: An 84-year-old man with end-stage progressive idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis, who has received home hospice care for 4 months, suddenly begins refusing food.  The patient had previously tolerated regular food and fluid intake, which his family provides daily.  His symptoms of respiratory distress and pain are managed with palliative medications but have worsened significantly over the past 2 weeks.  The patient is emaciated and bedbound.  The patient tells the hospice nurse and the physician that he wants to "go on a fast" and expresses his desire to avoid all food and liquid.  He states, "I know this means I could die sooner, but I have lived a full life.  I can feel that my time is near, and I am at peace."  The patient's family expresses grief and emotional distress after hearing his request.  The patient is alert and fully oriented without evidence of cognitive impairment.  Which of the following is the most appropriate next action?
questionList.explanationText:
Goals of patient care (eg, hospice care) in terminal illness include preserving patient autonomy and prioritizing patient comfort.  Patients with terminal illness may voluntarily cease fluid and food intake (ie, voluntarily stopping of eating and drinking [VSED]) to signal a symbolic readiness for death.  Although VSED can potentially increase a patient's physical suffering and may hasten death, it can also increase psychological comfort by promoting autonomy over the dying process.

When a patient requests VSED, the physician should proceed as follows:

  • Confirm that the patient is cognitively intact and that the request for VSED is voluntary and not influenced by mental illness

  • Counsel the patient (and family members) regarding possible consequences, including severe thirst and associated discomfort

  • Discuss alternatives to VSED (eg, continuing fluids only, decreasing rather than eliminating oral intake)

  • Discuss and clearly record the patient's preferences for managing discomfort (eg, small sips of fluids, oral swabbing, ice chips) because delirium and cognitive impairment may occur

(Choice A)  Ethics consultation is not necessary because this patient has no evidence of cognitive impairment and is receiving hospice care, with advanced illness and poor prognosis.

(Choice C)  Although VSED is likely to hasten death, it generally falls within the purview of patient autonomy and does not differ in principle from other patient refusals (eg, Do Not Resuscitate order).

(Choice D)  The principle of beneficence requires a physician to act in the patient's interest to relieve suffering but does not supersede a competent patient's informed decision and autonomy to choose VSED.

(Choice E)  In most cases, management of thirst symptoms with intravenous fluids is not recommended because it does not improve patient comfort or reduce delirium severity.

Educational objective:
Voluntarily Stopping of Eating and Drinking is a decision by patients with terminal illness to cease all food and fluid intake, often as a symbolic acceptance of death.  Physicians should verify that the patient has decision-making capacity and is acting voluntarily, provide counseling regarding potential consequences (eg, discomfort), and record preferences for comfort (eg, oral swabbing) in case of thirst-induced cognitive impairment (eg, delirium).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: End of life care

answerChoiceList.choice: Arrange an ethics consultation to determine whether the patient's request can be honored
Counsel the patient on potential consequences and record his preferences for comfort measures
Counsel the patient that his request cannot be honored because it is intended to hasten death
Counsel the patient that his request cannot be honored because it violates the principle of beneficence
Withhold oral intake but administer intravenous fluids if the patient develops clinical dehydration

questionList.questionText: A 68-year-old man with a history of type 2 diabetes mellitus is hospitalized with septic knee arthritis.  A peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC) is placed for administration of intravenous antibiotics.  Seven days later, a nurse notes redness and drainage around the patient's catheter insertion site.  Blood cultures subsequently reveal gram-positive cocci in clusters, and the catheter is removed.  Which of the following recommendations is most effective in reducing risk of this complication?
questionList.explanationText:
Prevention of central line–associated bloodstream infections

Catheter insertion

  • Hand hygiene (prior to use of gloves)
  • Full barrier precautions (eg, mask, sterile gloves, gown, drape)
  • Preparation of skin with chlorhexidine solution
  • Procedure performed by experienced provider

Catheter type and site

  • Use of PICCs and tunneled catheters
  • For CVCs, use of subclavian and internal jugular vein sites over femoral vein

Catheter duration

  • Limit duration (eg, <6 days) for CVCs
  • Prompt removal of catheter when no longer needed
  • Avoid routine replacement of CVCs

CVC = central venous catheter; PICC = peripherally inserted central catheter.

This patient has blood cultures demonstrating gram-positive cocci after placement of a peripherally inserted central catheter (PICC), with associated erythema and drainage around the insertion site.  This presentation indicates likely central line–associated bloodstream infection (CLABSI).

CLABSIs are an important preventable cause of patient morbidity and mortality.  Organisms implicated in CLABSIs are typically skin flora pathogens (eg, coagulase-negative staphylococci, Staphylococcus aureus), which enter the bloodstream from the skin of the patient or hands of the provider.  Therefore, provider hand hygiene (eg, cleansing of hands with antimicrobial soap and water or alcohol-based antiseptic) remains a fundamental, highly efficacious intervention preventing CLABSIs.  Providers should thoroughly wash hands or use alcohol-based sanitizer prior to initiating sterile technique, which includes use of sterile gloves, mask, gown, and drape.  Despite extensive resources and training, achieving high hand hygiene compliance among healthcare workers is often challenging.

Other risk-reduction practices for CLABSIs include use of chlorhexidine solution to thoroughly clean the patient's skin, placement by a provider with significant experience, and prompt removal of the catheter when no longer needed or when infection is suspected.

CLABSI risk also varies by type of insertion (central vs peripheral) of the central venous access devices.  Central venous catheters (CVCs), which are placed directly in the internal jugular, subclavian, or femoral vein, are associated with a higher CLABSI risk compared to peripherally inserted central catheters (ie, PICC lines), which are inserted in the peripheral veins of the upper extremities (eg, basilic vein) and threaded centrally (Choice B).  In addition, recent evidence suggests that catheters impregnated with antimicrobials (eg, with chlorhexidine or silver sulfadiazine) have some benefit in reducing CLABSIs and may emerge as an additional preventive mechanism.

(Choice A)  Application of topical antibiotic cream over the insertion site for non-hemodialysis central venous catheters, such as the PICC line described in this scenario, is not recommended due to increased risk of antimicrobial resistance and colonization with Candida species.

(Choice C)  Catheter maintenance involves regular dressing changes and cleansing of access sites (eg, ports) with alcohol antiseptic, rather than soap.  The area of the insertion site should remain dry, and water contact should be avoided.

(Choice E)  Administering oral antibiotics for CLABSI prophylaxis is not recommended due to increased risk of antimicrobial resistance and Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile infection; hand hygiene is a more effective infection-control measure.

Educational objective:
Catheter-associated bloodstream infections typically involve pathogens associated with skin flora.  Adherence to hand hygiene and use of sterile technique (eg, use of gloves, gown, mask, sterile drape, chlorhexidine solution preparation) remain the most important infection prevention measures.  Peripheral, rather than central, insertion of the catheter is also associated with lower risk of infection.
questionList.subject: Surgery
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Application of topical antibiotic cream over catheter insertion site
Central rather than peripheral insertion of catheter
Daily cleansing of catheter insertion site with antimicrobial soap and water
Hand washing with antimicrobial soap prior to catheter insertion
Prophylactic administration of oral antibiotics prior to catheter insertion

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Guidelines for the prevention of intravascular catheter-related infections.
Strategies to prevent central line-associated bloodstream infections in acute care hospitals: 2014 update.

questionList.questionText: A 37-year-old previously healthy man comes to the emergency department due to worsening cough and dyspnea for the past several days.  Evaluation shows tachycardia, tachypnea, labored breathing, and hypoxemia on room air.  Chest x-ray reveals diffuse bilateral interstitial infiltrates.  The patient states he has had unprotected sex with multiple partners.  He is not married and does not have any children.  Rapid HIV testing is positive.  The diagnosis is discussed with the patient, and hospital admission for treatment of hypoxic respiratory failure due to suspected Pneumocystis pneumonia is recommended.  The patient agrees but does not want any of his family members to know about the HIV diagnosis.  Which of the following is the best course of action?
questionList.explanationText:
Protected health information (PHI) (ie, personally identifiable information regarding diagnosis and/or treatment of any medical condition) should not be disclosed to others without patient consent.  This patient's request not to discuss his diagnosis with his family should be respected.  However, he has Pneumocystis pneumonia with signs of significant respiratory instability (ie, tachypnea, hypoxemia, labored breathing) and is at risk for unexpected, acute deterioration in clinical status.  Therefore, it is important to discuss his wishes regarding a surrogate decision-maker in the event he is unable to communicate his decisions for himself.

In most jurisdictions, when a patient is unable to make decisions regarding medical care and has not designated a surrogate decision-maker, decision-making falls to the next of kin default surrogate.  In this case, this possibility would greatly complicate the patient's care because he does not wish to share the details of his condition with his family.  Therefore, the care team should promptly discuss designating an alternate surrogate decision-maker outside the family (eg, close friend).

(Choices B and C)  The patient should be aware that it can be extremely difficult to indefinitely conceal chronic conditions (eg, HIV) from immediate family.  However, only the patient can decide whether, when, and to whom PHI may be disclosed.  He should not be pressured to disclose information to his family before he is ready.

(Choice D)  The attending physician and care team should always provide appropriate counsel to patients and surrogate decision-makers, but in general a treating physician may not be designated as a decision-maker.  A more appropriate surrogate decision-maker should be identified as soon as possible.

(Choice E)  There is no obligation to disclose PHI to a family member without patient consent.  If a family member insists on discussing PHI with the physician, the physician should simply state that he or she does not have the patient's consent for disclosure.

Educational objective:
When a patient is unable to make decisions regarding medical care and has not designated a surrogate decision-maker, decision-making falls to the next of kin default surrogate.  Patients who wish not to inform family members of protected health information should designate an alternate surrogate decision-maker.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient confidentiality

answerChoiceList.choice: Accept the patient's decision and help him identify a surrogate decision-maker other than family
Attempt to convince the patient to tell his family about the diagnosis
Explain that his diagnosis cannot be concealed indefinitely and arrange a family meeting
Respect the patient's wishes and offer that the physician team could make decisions if he becomes incapacitated
Tell the patient that you must answer truthfully if his family insists on receiving information

questionList.questionText: An 81-year-old woman with a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and mitral valve replacement, maintained on warfarin, is admitted to the intensive care unit due to pneumonia.  The patient develops asymptomatic runs of ventricular tachycardia.  A cross-covering provider, who is normally based in a different unit, pages the attending physician.  The physician is performing a sterile procedure in another unit and asks a resident to communicate a verbal phone order for 20 mEq of oral potassium supplementation.  The resident states the order as, "Give 20 of K now."  The cross-covering provider enters the verbal order as, "Give 20 mg of vitamin K intravenously now."  The patient receives the medication.  The following day, her INR is subtherapeutic.  Which of the following could have prevented this error?
questionList.explanationText:
Strategies to improve health care communication

Strategy

Description

Benefits

Standardized
handoff

Checklist or other systematic process frames provider-to-provider discussion during sign-out

Ensures consistency and reliability, reduces errors of omission

Closed-loop
communication/
"read-backs"

Sender relays message to receiver, receiver repeats information back to sender & sender confirms that message is correct

Minimizes errors of misinterpretation and misunderstanding

Interdisciplinary rounds

Team members represent multiple disciplines (eg, nursing, pharmacy)

Increases continuous learning and collaborative oversight of patient's condition

Team huddles
& debriefing

Brief, interdisciplinary discussions of patient concerns and risks; held prior to, during, &/or after clinical event

Reduces hierarchical barriers, encourages speaking up & promotes shared team safety goals

Team-based
training

Train team members together via interactive formats (eg, simulation)

Improves communication & collaboration, promotes group learning & reduces hierarchical barriers

Poor communication is a leading cause of medical errors (~66% of sentinel events, or serious adverse events resulting in irreversible patient harm).  In this case, communication breakdown caused inadvertent administration of intravenous vitamin K rather than oral potassium (sometimes given empirically because electrolyte abnormalities exacerbate arrhythmias), resulting in reversal of warfarin-induced anticoagulation (ie, subtherapeutic INR level).  Miscommunication risk increases with verbal orders, which lack safety checkpoints (eg, computerized alerts indicating drug interactions).  Abbreviations (eg, "20 of K," instead of full dose and drug name) and indirect communication (eg, resident communication of attending's order) also increase error risk.

Closed-loop communication, also known as "read-back" technique, is used by high-reliability organizations (eg, those with excellent safety records despite high risk) to minimize miscommunication.  This technique is as follows:

  1. Sender (eg, resident) conveys message (eg, specific potassium order) to receiver (eg, cross-covering provider).

  2. Receiver repeats (reads back) the full interpreted message to sender.

  3. Sender clarifies or confirms accuracy of message.

Use of closed-loop communication would have identified and corrected this miscommunicated verbal order.

(Choice A)  Visual cues, such as warning labels, can prevent confusion between look-alike or high-risk medications (eg, clear antibiotic solution bags with similar appearance to intravenous fluids).  In this case, selection of the wrong drug resulted from a miscommunicated verbal order rather than confusion between look-alike medications.

(Choice B)  Clinical decision support tools prompt providers who place orders using computerized systems to consider safety-promoting actions (eg, review drug-drug interaction).  These tools are unlikely to generate alerts for vitamin K (which may be appropriate corrective therapy when INR reversal is desired); furthermore, they would not prevent errors from verbal orders.

(Choices D and E)  Checklists improve safety by standardizing high-risk processes (eg, preventing incomplete sign-out) and administration of high-risk medications (eg, administering tissue plasminogen activator to patients with suspected stroke).  Checklists and standardized sign-outs would not prevent incorrect drug selection resulting from miscommunication of real-time verbal orders.

Educational objective:
Communication breakdowns, a leading cause of medical error, are more likely to occur with abbreviations, verbal orders, or third-party messages.  Closed-loop communication increases communication accuracy and reduces medical error risk.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Adding warning labels to look-alike drugs
Implementing a clinical decision support protocol
Practicing closed-loop technique
Standardizing sign-out communication
Using checklists prior to high-risk drug administration

questionList.questionText: An 11-year-old girl is seen in the clinic for a follow-up visit.  She was diagnosed with B-cell acute lymphoblastic leukemia 4 weeks ago and just completed induction chemotherapy.  Repeat bone marrow evaluation today shows a persistently elevated percentage of blast cells.  The patient's parents have previously stated that they "do not want anything negative" said to their daughter about her diagnosis or prognosis.  While speaking in private, the patient says, "My mom says I'll be better soon, but I don't feel like I'm getting better.  I know that everyone dies, but I don't know when that's going to happen to me."  Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questionList.explanationText:
Patient-physician relationships are based on respect for patient autonomy, which includes ensuring that patients are provided with adequate medical information at an appropriate level.  In pediatric populations, there is added complexity of integrating respect for parent authority with the obligation to be honest with patients.  At times, parents request that information be withheld from their child, forcing the physician to balance obligations to the patient with parent wishes.

However, the physician's primary duty is to the patient.  Cases of chronic or terminal illness with poor prognosis require responsiveness to emerging patient concerns to ease distress and provide assurance of continued support.  In this scenario, the patient suggests fears of potential death (eg, "I don't know when that's going to happen to me") and uncertainty about her treatment (eg, "I don't feel like I'm getting better").  The most appropriate response is to determine the patient's current understanding about her condition in order to empathically provide timely comfort and support.

Gaining insight into the child's understanding can also eventually guide ongoing conversations with parents to collaboratively develop a detailed plan for disclosure, specifying timing, approach, and extent of information shared while allowing a space to support and educate as well.  Until then, the physician should respect the parents' request to avoid overtly discussing "anything negative."  Such requests generally stem from concerns about a child's psychologic well-being; however, research suggests openness helps with longer-term adjustment, whereas withholding information may cause distress (eg, children developing beliefs they did something to deserve the pain).

(Choices A and C)  Encouraging communication between parents and their child with a chronic or terminal illness is a vital physician role; however, serious patient concerns (eg, fear of death, uncertainty about treatment) should be addressed in the moment without deferring the discussion to others or unreasonably expecting the child to introduce the subject herself.

(Choice D)  It is unknown if this patient will improve after another round of chemotherapy, and the physician should not offer evasive statements to avoid difficult discussions.

(Choice E)  The conversation may eventually include a patient-directed discussion about death and dying; however, immediately raising this topic is too abrupt without first understanding what the patient knows about her condition.  In addition, doing so would dismiss the parents' request to withhold negative information.

Educational objective:
In pediatric patients with a chronic or terminal illness and poor prognosis, the patient's understanding should first be determined before making a detailed plan with parents for disclosure.
questionList.subject: Pediatrics
questionList.title: Advance directive/surrogate decision maker

answerChoiceList.choice: Ask the patient for permission to share her concerns with her parents
Determine what the patient understands about her condition and treatment response
Encourage the patient to talk to her parents about her concerns
Explain that the patient will likely feel better after another round of chemotherapy
Inquire about the patient's perception of death and dying

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Minors' right to know and therapeutic privilege.

questionList.questionText:
The following vignette applies to the next 2 items.  The items in the set must be answered in sequential order.  Once you click Proceed to Next Item, you will not be able to add or change an answer.

Item 1 of 2

A retrospective chart review is conducted at a busy urgent care clinic to analyze diagnostic errors related to spinal epidural abscess (SEA).  The analysis finds that preventable delays in diagnosis occurred in 60% of patients with back pain who were ultimately found to have SEA.  Delayed diagnosis occurred even when patients were documented by the physician to have red flag symptoms, such as unexplained fever or focal neurological deficits.  Results of the analysis are shown in the table below:

Factors associated with preventable delays in SEA diagnosis

Type of error

Percentage of cases

Red flags not documented by physician during encounter

~40%

Red flags documented but physician does not order follow-up tests

~40%

Lack of prompt follow-up when tests reveal concerning findings

~10%

Patient misses appointment for scheduled follow-up

~10%

These data suggest which of the following underlying factors is most commonly associated with SEA-related diagnostic errors at this clinic?
questionList.explanationText:
Common cognitive errors in medicine

Type of bias

Definition

Example

Anchoring

  • Fixating on initial impressions to make a diagnosis
  • Related to confirmation bias & premature closure
  • Burning throat pain diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss
  • Correct diagnosis is lung malignancy

Availability

  • Allowing recently seen or memorable (high-stakes) cases to sway diagnosis
  • Dyspnea diagnosed as influenza during peak influenza season
  • Correct diagnosis is pulmonary embolism

Confirmation

  • Emphasizing evidence that supports presumed diagnosis & overlooking information that supports other diagnoses
  • Related to anchoring bias
  • Burning throat pain after eating spicy food diagnosed as acid reflux despite weight loss
  • Correct diagnosis is malignancy

Framing

  • Allowing diagnostic approach to be influenced by context & presentation of information
  • Abdominal pain diagnosed as opioid withdrawal in patient described as drug seeking
  • Correct diagnosis is bowel obstruction

Spinal epidural abscess (SEA) is a rare but serious cause of back pain.  It should be suspected in patients with red flags (eg, fever, focal neurologic findings) or infection risk factors (eg, injection drug use, immunosuppression); however, the diagnosis is frequently missed (ie, diagnostic error).

Cognitive bias, which refers to unconscious mental shortcuts (eg, pattern recognition) used in medical decision-making, is a common cause of diagnostic error.  This clinic's data suggest that the following cognitive errors may be leading to delayed SEA diagnosis:

  • Red flags were not documented in ~40% of patients with SEA.  Physicians more commonly see patients with musculoskeletal back pain and may unconsciously miss clinical features suggesting a more serious diagnosis such as SEA.  This may reflect availability bias, occurring when the differential diagnosis is incorrectly narrowed to common, more cognitively "available" (eg, musculoskeletal back pain) diagnoses.

  • Physicians did not order follow-up tests despite documenting red flags in 40% of patients, suggesting unconscious oversight of this information. This may reflect confirmation bias (related to anchoring bias), occurring when physicians prematurely fixate on a presumptive diagnosis (eg, musculoskeletal back pain) and unconsciously disregard information that supports an alternate diagnosis.

Although mental shortcuts can improve efficiency, overreliance can lead to errors, particularly in settings of cognitive overload (eg, high patient volume, multitasking), as in this busy urgent care clinic.

(Choice A)  Electronic medical record (EMR) system complexity is unlikely to explain the lack of red flag documentation seen in 40% of cases of SEA.  Although EMR complexity may lead to incorrect orders being placed (eg, incorrect MRI order), it is less likely to explain not ordering follow-up tests.

(Choice B)  Patient complexity is unlikely to explain why physicians did not order follow-up testing even when red flags were noted.  On the contrary, physician perception of high patient complexity tends to promote application of a systematic, comprehensive approach to diagnosis (eg, increased likelihood of considering more diagnoses).

(Choice C)  Inadequate team communication can impair coordination of care (eg, appropriate patient follow-up), but this accounts for only a minority (eg, ~10%) of delayed diagnoses at this clinic.

Educational objective:
Cognitive overload (eg, due to a high-pressure environment or multitasking) can lead to diagnostic errors.  Availability bias occurs when the differential diagnosis is incorrectly narrowed to common diagnoses.  Confirmation bias occurs when physicians prematurely fixate on a presumptive diagnosis and unconsciously disregard information that supports an alternate diagnosis.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Complex electronic medical record
High patient complexity
Inadequate team communication
Physician cognitive overload

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Errors in diagnosis of spinal epidural abscesses in the era of electronic health records.

questionList.questionText:
Item 2 of 2

Based on the data shown, which of the following interventions is most likely to reduce the frequency of delayed diagnosis at this clinic?
questionList.explanationText:
Electronic decision support tools can optimize physician decision-making and reduce cognitive overload in busy, complex settings where risk of cognitive bias is highest.  These tools are typically integrated in the electronic medical record and provide real-time, interactive feedback and guidance for physicians.  They reduce diagnostic errors through the following:

  • Reminding physicians of relevant patient information from previous encounters (eg, history of injection drug use as a risk factor for infection)

  • Prompting physicians to perform specific actions during the history and physical examination to thoroughly assess risk (eg, asking about fever during evaluation of back pain)

  • Providing quick access to evidence-based algorithms or clinical pathways that outline recommended steps in patient care (eg, ordering inflammatory markers, such as erythrocyte sedimentation rate, in patients with fever and back pain).

(Choice A)  Although care coordination can improve patient follow-up, it is unlikely to reduce cognitive bias and the resulting diagnostic errors.

(Choice C)  Root-cause analysis is useful if the causes of error are unclear.  However, in this case, analysis has already been performed with data suggesting cognitive bias as the primary cause.

(Choice D)  The causes of delayed diagnosis in this clinic are more likely related to cognitive bias in the setting of cognitive overload rather than inadequate training.  Additional training is likely to add to physician burden without addressing the underlying problem.

(Choice E)  Inflammatory markers have low specificity for infection in patients with back pain; laboratory testing should be performed selectively, not automatically, based on clinical features.

Educational objective:
Electronic decision support tools prompt physicians to consider specific actions (eg, ordering tests) and alert them to relevant patient information (eg, previously documented risk factors).  These tools can reduce cognitive overload in busy, complex settings and can prevent diagnostic error.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Care coordinators and multidisciplinary teams that facilitate patient follow-up testing
Electronic decision support tools that prompt physicians during evaluation and management of back pain
Periodic root-cause analysis examining factors contributing to delayed and missed diagnoses
Simulation-based training that targets physicians' history-taking and physical examination skills
Standardized laboratory protocols that automatically screen for inflammatory markers in patients with back pain

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Prospective evaluation of a clinical decision guideline to diagnose spinal epidural abscess in patients who present to the emergency department with spine pain.
