questionList.questionText: A 26-year-old primigravida woman at 38 weeks gestation is admitted to the hospital due to preeclampsia with severe features.  She undergoes emergency cesarean delivery of a healthy newborn.  After delivery, the patient continues to have uncontrolled hypertension and suffers an ischemic stroke.  She is intubated and placed on full ventilator support.  On day 3 of hospitalization, the patient remains minimally responsive to most stimuli.  She has no advance directive.  The physician explains the clinical findings, prognosis, and options for care to the patient's husband and parents.  The husband says he has never specifically discussed life-sustaining medical treatment with her.  The patient's parents state that it would be best to continue life support because the patient just became a mother.  In further discussion with the husband and parents, which of the following would be most important for the physician to address?
questionList.explanationText:
In the absence of an advance directive (eg, living will, patient-designated health care proxy) to guide medical decisions for incapacitated patients (eg, minimally responsive, comatose), those decisions fall to nondesignated substitute decision makers, with proximity of relationship establishing priority (eg, spouse > adult child > parent).  However, the fundamental guiding principle in all substitute decision-making is the obligation to uphold the substituted judgment standard (ie, what the patient would have chosen if she had retained decision-making capacity).

In situations where the patient has no clearly established treatment preference, individuals most intimate with the patient are in the best position to integrate familiarity of the patient's background, values, and beliefs with clinical findings, prognosis, and options for care to estimate what the patient would have chosen.  Although the husband is the default surrogate and would be responsible for making medical decisions, in this scenario, a conversation between the husband and parents should be encouraged to foster a better understanding of what the patient would have chosen.  However, in line with the substituted judgment standard, the husband's medical decisions should not be based on his own preference for the patient's treatment but rather on his perception of what his wife would have chosen (Choice B).

If the husband were not present, the parents would be responsible for making medical decisions; however, they would similarly be obligated to make those decisions in accordance with their best estimate of what the patient would have chosen and not their own value judgments and preferences (Choice D).

(Choices C and E)  Thorough discussion and understanding of clinical findings, prognoses (eg, likelihood of a meaningful recovery, outcomes of prolonged mechanical ventilation), and medical options (which must always include risk/benefit discussions) are necessary to uphold patient autonomy through informed consent; however, the most important consideration is how the substitute decision maker estimates the patient would have incorporated this information if decision-making capacity were retained.

Educational objective:
In the absence of an advance directive, decision-making for an incapacitated patient is based on the principle of the substituted judgment standard.  The surrogate decision maker is obligated to base medical decisions on his or her best judgment of what the patient would have chosen.
questionList.subject: Obstetrics & Gynecology
questionList.title: Advance directive/surrogate decision maker

answerChoiceList.choice: Husband's and parents' perceptions of what the patient would have wanted
Husband's preference for the patient's treatment
Likelihood that the patient will have a meaningful recovery
Parents' preference for the patient's treatment
Risk of medical complications with prolonged mechanical ventilation

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Capacity for preferences: respecting patients with compromised decision-making.

questionList.questionText: During a particularly busy winter season, the medical director of a primary care clinic implements a strategic plan to reduce iatrogenic transmission of respiratory viruses among patients and staff within the clinic.  As part of the plan, all clinic staff complete an in-service training on infection control and influenza vaccine counseling practices; additional dispensers of hand sanitizer are installed in prominent, high-traffic areas; and an updated ventilation system is installed to improve air circulation.  In addition, patients in the waiting room are provided masks if they are experiencing cough or fever, and all eligible patients receive enhanced counseling and educational materials promoting influenza vaccine administration.  This strategic plan best represents which of the following approaches to increase safety?
questionList.explanationText:
The Swiss Cheese Model (SCM) is a strategy often used in health care organizations to increase safety.  SCM recommends overlapping multiple barriers (visualized as slices of cheese) within a process to block hazards.  Targeted hazards include both internal human error (eg, mistakes resulting from fatigue) and external threats (eg, infectious agents).

SCM is based on the following principles:

  • No single defensive barrier (eg, handwashing) is fully error proof; each intervention contains "holes" or vulnerabilities (eg, forgetting to wash hands, incorrect handwashing technique) that can enable an adverse outcome (eg, transmission of infection).
  • Harm occurs when hazards pass unchecked through holes in defensive barriers.
  • Stacking multiple, overlapping "slices" or defensive barriers increases the likelihood that hazards will be detected early and downstream harm (ie, adverse patient outcome) will be blocked.

In this clinic, overlapping barriers against virus transmission include interventions targeting human effort (eg, masks, hand hygiene stations), medical care (eg, vaccination), and the physical environment (ventilation systems).  These barriers in combination are more effective in reducing transmission of infection than each barrier alone.

(Choice A)  Computerized automation can reduce errors in high-risk, manually performed processes (eg, automated calculation of drug infusion rates with an infusion pump).  None of this clinic's interventions involve automation.

(Choice B)  Forcing functions, also known as "hard stops," use physical design to prohibit incorrect action.  For example, oxygen and nitrous oxide gas containers can be designed with different, incompatible connectors, which eliminates accidental connections to the wrong cylinder.  Forcing functions are not seen in this clinic.

(Choice D)  Continuous quality improvement methods, such as the Plan-Do-Study-Act cycle, seek to improve a process by repeatedly testing, measuring, and refining a test of change.  This clinic's interventions are implemented concurrently rather than sequentially or cyclically.

Educational objective:
The Swiss Cheese Model (SCM) recommends overlapping multiple barriers to increase system safety.  SCM depicts each defensive barrier as having vulnerabilities (akin to holes in a slice of cheese); therefore, stacking together multiple interventions (ie, layers of cheese) can block hazards (eg, error caused by fatigue; infectious pathogen) from passing through the system to cause harm (ie, adverse patient outcome).
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: Automating high-risk action
Incorporation of "hard stops" against incorrect action
Overlapping barriers to block safety hazards
Repeated cycles of process improvement

questionMappingReferencesList.title: Understanding the "Swiss Cheese Model" and its application to patient safety.

questionList.questionText: A computerized infusion pump is being prepared to administer a continuous dose of a specific medication to a patient hospitalized in the intensive care unit.  The patient's physician writes a prescription to infuse the medication at a rate of 10 mg/hr.  However, the provider who programs the pump accidentally sets the infusion rate to 100 mg/hr.  Internal investigations reveal that other medication errors involving incorrectly programmed infusion pumps have occurred in the institution.  A root cause analysis is recommended.  The primary purpose of this analysis is to identify which of the following?
questionList.explanationText:
Common tools used in error analysis

Root cause analysis (event analysis)

  • Retrospective
  • Identifies all underlying reasons (systems & personnel-related) that an error occurred

Failure modes & effects analysis

  • Prospective
  • Identifies the likelihood & potential sources of system failures before error occurs

Common cause analysis

  • Retrospective
  • Identifies most common themes & trends present among multiple errors

Morbidity & mortality conference

  • Retrospective
  • Identify system-level improvements to address an error through confidential, interdisciplinary, standardized group discussion

Root cause analysis (RCA), also known as event analysis, is a comprehensive, retrospective error analysis tool.  The primary purpose of RCA is to identify all underlying causes of an error or series of errors.  Causes may include both active factors (ie, human error, incorrect actions of multiple personnel), which are often readily apparent but only partially explain why an error occurred, and latent factors (ie, system-level deficiencies such as overly confusing infusion pump controls).

RCA may use the following approaches:

  • Iteratively asking "why" errors occurred until all underlying causes are identified (eg, 5 Whys approach)

  • Rendering a cause-and-effect diagram (ie, fishbone diagram), which visually depicts relationships among factors contributing to error (eg, personnel, devices, environment)

  • Making a process map, which visually outlines steps to systematically identify where errors occurred

(Choice A)  A personnel-focused analysis generates a superficial and incomplete error analysis (ie, considers only active factors) and omits latent factors.  In contrast, RCA addresses both active and latent causes.

(Choices B and D)  Failure mode and effects analysis (FMEA) is a prospective review (used before errors occur) intended to identify the system vulnerabilities potentially causing error and the likelihood of potential errors within a process.  FMEA is often used to guide development of new organizational protocols or processes.  In contrast, RCA is a retrospective review looking at errors that have already occurred.

(Choice E)  Identifying the most common trends and themes behind multiple error events is the goal of common cause analysis (rather than RCA).  Common cause analysis, which sometimes aggregates data from multiple RCAs, can help prioritize safety improvements at the level of the organization, leadership, or environment of care, whereas RCA tends to be helpful in identifying issues with specific processes (eg, infusion pumps).

Educational objective:
Root cause analysis (event analysis) is a comprehensive, retrospective error analysis tool.  The objective is to identify all underlying causes of error, including both latent (ie, system level) and active (ie, personnel level) factors.
questionList.subject: Medicine
questionList.title: Patient safety

answerChoiceList.choice: All personnel involved in incorrect programming of infusion pumps
All system vulnerabilities that could potentially cause future infusion pump programming errors
All underlying reasons why these particular infusion pump errors occurred
Likelihood of errors at various points in the process of infusion pump operation
The most common themes present among multiple medication and infusion pump errors
